description:
If you come to Chrissy Field, walk towards the Golden Gate Bridge and visit Fort Point. Amazing views, especially on clear day. Come when it's cold and foggy, and get the true feeling of SF weather. I have been here a few times and this last go round was with our son. He's 11 and loves to learn about history. He enjoyed seeing the canons, walking in the rooms, and most of all, being under the Golden Gate Bridge. There is parking right at Fort Point. Limited though. My suggestion is to park at Chrissy field, and walk here. You get walking exercise, great views of the city, Bridge and water activity, and veer off to take some trails.  

When walking to Ft. Point, please be careful.  Some of those driving to Ft. Point don't always follow the 15 mph rule and the driving space can get tight between those walking, runners, on bikes, strollers, etc.  There is a bathroom stop either at Chrissy Field or right before Ft. Point.  There is no cost to enter Ft Point, but there is a donation box present right at the entrance.  The stairs to walk to the top of the building is pretty steep so be careful.  Watch your little ones too that may want to run around.
author: Viclaire S.

description:
Not much to add - I think the pictures on this page speak for itself. Lived here for over 4 years and last weekend was my first time visiting... TOOK ME LONG ENOUGH. Usually when I have out of town guests I take them to the Golden Gate Visitor Center to check out the Vista Point... I think from now on I'll start taking them to Fort Point for a couple of reasons:

1. The city views are spectacular and give you better photos of the bridge (IMO). Like walking under the Eiffel Tower, Fort Point allows you to see under the bridge and appreciate its structure. If it's super foggy during your visit to SF, come here so you at least have something to see.

2. Less crowded compared to the Golden Gate Visitor center... I think it's mainly because unless you walk from the visitor center, there isn't a bus that comes through there. I don't see the tour group buses come here as well. This makes the experience more enjoyable without the constant parade of selfie sticks and iPad photos.

3. It's free; there is no admission to visit Fort Point itself. Technically the visitor center is free, but you have to pay for the parking. At Fort Point, they have free parking spaces and even if you have to park far down on the waterfront, the walk isn't that bad. Also parking is relatively easy because there are people constantly coming/going.

4. I thought the fort itself was more interesting - there are exhibits around the fort like the kitchens, officer's quarters, gunpowder room, etc. The fort also provided great views of the bay, and it was fun to walk around it in general. There was a lot of history to appreciate 

There are restrooms before the entrance to the fort - unlike the women's restroom line at the Golden Gate Visitor Center, it's shorter (but just as gross). Also I highly recommend bringing a light jacket - it was SUPER WINDY when we came here... especially when we got to the top floor of the fort. The Bay Area is notorious from going from hot to cold due to wind chill factor.

Honestly the only annoyance I had about this place was driving to it - you'll have to deal with a lot of pedestrians crossing and sharing the road with bikers. It gets frustrating being behind a biker trying to go up the hill... there doesn't seem to be any road etiquette.
author: Alyanna C.

description:
Awesome views from underneath the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz ,and the San Francisco skyline. When coming from the North End of the bridge this is my 3rd stop in Golden Gate Bridge viewing and photo stop process. Fort is only open on certain days so make sure you check the schedule and plan accordingly if you would like to go inside of the fort. No fee is involved for walking through the fort so this is another must stop in the San Francisco area viewing process. 

Parking,photos, and walking through the fort if you're doing it in a quick fashion takes about 30 minutes. It's always windy and cold definitely  make sure you bring a sweatshirt when viewing the fort to make it an enjoyable experience.
author: James F.

description:
this review isn't for Fort Point itself because it was closed when we got there super early but do you know how long Ive been trying to get down here under this bridge to this spot????  This was my 3rd try.  3rd tries a charm right!  Well in this case, it sure the heck was.  FINALLY!
Got down here about 8am.  The view is amazing from down under I tell ya.  Ive been up top, pointing trying to figure out how to get here lol.  Had a jog from one end to the other, people everywhere just enjoying and living their best life.  This is THEE BEST place to see the bridge, no doubt.
author: Lynette C.

description: Over all great place to hangout, chill and take some awesome photos of the bridge.Parking is available and free I believe they have a small museum accessible to the public only that we got there too late to take a tour. Don't sleep on this gem.
author: Benito Z.

description: First time at this spot I have to say was a good spot after all. We got a get a good look at the Golden Gate Bridge from here we'll be back at this spot for sure
author: Maria P.

description:
No surprise this place has 5 stars. I've visited annually for decades and it's always kept so clean and nice. Free admission but parking can be tricky if you come on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon. I usually come in the mornings or weekdays and it's no issue. 

You can stand both very near and under the bridge and get some amazing shots. Dress warm because it's super chilly and windy!
author: Attosa C.

description:
Fort Point brings a great Bay vibe that will relax your inner mind as you inhale fresh air from the surrounding cold breezes of the Pacific Ocean. This place has a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge, meaning this is a popular destination for tourists to go take iconic San Franciscan pictures with the historic bridge. 

This place is a very dog friendly place as Crissy fields is right along this strip, which offers a large grass field where dogs of any size can go running.

Restrooms are available, however lines may be long. There is parking available much closer to the bridge, so keep driving further down if you're coming from Presidio. Keep in mind that you'll need to pay for parking if you come during the weekends.

Please be extra cautious as there are bikers along the area so if you're driving be sure to check your blind spots. There has been times were bikers have almost gotten hit. And if you plan to bike, you should also be extra cautious of cars, don't think you have the right of way all the time, or that drivers are always able to spot you.

There is a trail/ stairs that will lead you up to the bridge, but it's a bit of a walk.
author: Marc C.

description:
Hide away at the base of the Golden Gate Bridge, and gaze up at the underbelly of that beautiful piece of architecture. My first memory of this place was as an eleven-year-old, and I've been back a few times since then.

To really understand and appreciate it, you just have to stand there, jaw agape, looking at the bridge. You just have to see it. I would take you there, and we would get as close as we can to the bridge, and we'd just stand there and you'd understand. I'd probably go on and on about the bridge, and the view, and boats, and the people, and the water, and surf, and the spray, but hopefully you wouldn't mind because that view is worth it.

It's not just about the bridge. In fact, it really should be all about the fort. Remember that the Bay has always been an important port for the western US, and this fort was one of many installations designed to make sure it was secure from attack by sea. There still exists today a vestige of this, and although the urban sprawl of even a greenspace respecting city like San Francisco wants to inch in, it's really nice to see the preserved fort as an homage to a time now past.

I wonder what it was like, in those days. To be stationed here. To wonder if today, or tomorrow, or never was the moment you would need to spring into motion. I bet it took its toll sometimes, always being at the ready, but never knowing if you would ever be called into action. I'd like to think I would have been ready. These days, I have things I try to be ready for, though mine are hopeful and forward-facing things, and I try to be ready. But sometimes those things are out of our hands.

In their case, they were never called into action. No major attacks. And now it's more a museum dedicated to readiness than a memorial based on hard fought battles. 

This spot is hardly a secret, but it's one that oft gets overlooked. If I was planning a trip to SF, I'd surely like to make a stop here. We'd stand there underneath the bridge and talk about yesteryear and all that time of having to be ready, and take pictures, and smell the ocean spray when it crashed into the rocks.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Some great views of the bay and the bridge. 

Free admission and they have a decent self guided tour of the history of the fort. I loved getting to see the many uses it has had in the past century. Go up to the top for an up close look at the underside of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Ramses C.

description:
This a must see view from under the Golden Gate Bridge.  The view is great.  There is museum which Is nice. Fort Point is great photo vista point.    
Parking can be a challenge, the restroom is in the museum.  There are not chairs or table to hang out.  
Bring a sweater, it can get chilly.
author: Liz B.

description:
My buddy and I made it there right on time for sunset, and perfectly clear weather. I guess we got lucky. The views were amazing and it was lovely to see the Golden Gate Bridge on last time before I move to the the south west side of the USA.

Like Douglas Cross famously said in his most known song:

"I left my heart in San Francisco
High on a hill, it calls to me
To be where little cable cars climb halfway to the stars
The morning fog may chill the air, I don't care

My love waits there in San Francisco
Above the blue and windy sea
When I come home to you, San Francisco
Your golden sun will shine for me"

Till the next time San Francisco!
author: Jairo M.

description:
One of the coolest landmarks in the SF. I've honestly never noticed this fort underneath the Golden Gate. I've lived in the bay area my whole life and I only recently found this place. A couple of years ago, my friend proposed to this girlfriend on the top floor of the fort with 50 friends and family witnessing the magic.

This fort is opened to the public and there's no fee the enter. Parking is free if you are lucky enough to grab a space. I think most tourist walk, bike or shuttle here. I, of course, am super lazy so I will drive circles around the small lot until someone leaves.

The building is pretty much one huge outdoor museum so you can go into some of the rooms and read all about the history of the landmark. 

RESTROOM: None inside, it's located outside along the rocky wall.
author: Andrew T.

description: FREE attraction and FREE, but limited parking spots. Go during less peak hour if you don't want to fight over a parking spot. This was one of the best things I've done in San Francisco. You could just feel the history within the fort and the surrounding views of the bridge, downtown and Alcatraz were spectacular! Bring a jacket it gets cold and windy.
author: Zach H.

description:
5-Star, because places like this are always the same barring a natural disaster.  This is a beautiful place to see the Golden Gate, and the bay. There is a nice park and walking/running trails, and lots of other neat things to see and do.  It is a National Park now, having been a former military base, and worth the time to check out.  I recommend setting aside a few hours to do it right.  Lots to see and do here.  Bring your camera and be ready to get some beautiful nature and people shots!

Come check it out!
author: Will A.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city. I look forward to the views of the Golden Gate bridge on every run where Fort Point is my halfway turnaround. Be it hot and sunny or cold and foggy, Fort Point never fails to remind me why I love SF. And even more fun when the planes go by during Fleet Week! 

800th review and fittingly for a SF staple. Things come and go in the city but I never fail to take a moment to just soak it all in - the views of the city, the smell of the bay, and the sound of the crashing waves. Truly special and beautiful this place.
author: Jon L.

description: The closest point of view underneath the Golden Gate bridge. A historical battle site worth visiting for history buffs. Amazing views of the GG bridge and Bay.
author: Andrew P.

description:
They would be 5 star but I drove over 2 hours 2 times to find them closed. The sign and yelp say open but the doors were closed. The 2nd time I had another person drive over with me.... he came from Hollister.  Felt such a shame. Bridge patrol
Was also shocked they were closed at 13:30 in the afternoon.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I was given bad directions by my brother on how to get to Crissy Field, which somehow then led me and my parents to this rather beautiful Civil War-era fortress that anchors one end of the Golden Gate Bridge. So we were spontaneous tourists for about five minutes there.

Wow, what a view! It's a more spectacular view of the Bridge than being on the Bridge itself. It's apparently also the end of a very popular running trail that lines the south end of San Francisco Bay.
author: Henry T.

description:
Fort Point is always a great stop with kids.  It's free to get in, there is some parking, and it has a great view!  The bathroom facilities are not great, but bearable.

Today my son and I walked the (~0.5 mile) trail down to Fort Point from the Golden Gate Bridge visitor center since we got a parking space near there.  The walk/trail was easy and beautiful.

You can get your Passport to Your National Parks stamps inside the gift shop.
author: Tracy L.

description: Went here to take some good shots of the bridge, and it didn't disappoint. Not much parking so if you're coming at a popular time then good luck! It was an awesome vantage point though and I'll likely be back to walk around and enjoy the SF scenery.
author: Neechi M.

description:
What a beautiful place to view the Golden Gate Bridge. 
It was a bit cold today but we still enjoyed the park.
author: Bailey C.

description: Amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz from this area! You can also explore the fort and waterfront park!  This area is a little less windy than where we first decided to view the bridge. For a view from higher up go to the other side of highway 101.
author: Jennifer D.

description: If you're looking to do some exploring for free, this is the spot! I came here with my friend a few weeks ago and we enjoyed walking around the entire monument. Climb up to the roof to get a spectacular view of the ocean and the bottom of the Golden Gate Bridge. This was also a great spot to watch surfers taking advantage of the waves.
author: Christina P.

description: What an awesome experience! My favorite experience from my San Francisco trip. I recommend renting a bike and riding it over the bridge to Sausalito. If you get tired, get on the Ferry back to San Francisco after having a nice lunch at Sausalito. Lovely experience!
author: Mia P.

description:
Having lived in the Bay Area for the last 7 years I decided to take the family into town and play tourist.  There have been countless times that we have been on and over the Golden Gate.  However the vantage point of the bridge, headlands, and City offered by Fort Point is amazing!  Not crowded at all.  The Fort represents a engineering step back in time.  The brick work is top notch!  


What did I learn today?  Skip the masses up on the Bridge and enjoy a much less common, but more spectacular view from the Fort.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Such a cool landmark and piece of California : SF history! Located directly below the Golden Gate Bridge , you can't miss it! 

Small parking lot in front of the Fort. Ive always walked / biked in from Crissy field and this is my pit stop before crossing over the bridge . Such an amazing view ! Free to go inside and check out the Fort. Best spot is on top to snag a photo! Can get windy at times , but if you catch it on a nice clear sunny day , you'll never want to leave !
author: Eddy P.

description:
I think Fort Point is one of the best kept secrets hidden in plain sight when it comes to getting a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. On a day when I was showing visiting friends around SF, Pier 39 was a madhouse, while Fort Point had just a manageable trickle of visitors (and it doesn't suck, like Pier 39). I looked up and saw throngs of people on the top of the bridge, but it was relatively quiet down below.

While I've been out to Fort Point a handful of times, it has never been open when I've visited. I actually didn't even know it was open to visitors - but this time it was! And for free! It's really cool on the inside, and bigger than you might think from the outside. There are a decent number of exhibits - nothing too amazing, but I thought they were all interesting. You're able to walk through virtually the entire fort, including the top. The views of the bridge from the roof were fantastic, and getting that close to the bridge really makes you admire this feat of engineering.

Right now (summer), Fort Point is open Thursday-Monday from 10-5. I assume these times could change, so definitely check their website before going. Parking here is free and not too hard to come by. On your approach, you'll be entertained by watching the tourists who rented bikes struggling to walk them back up the hill they rode down. You could also conceivably walk here from Crissy Field or elsewhere if you so desired. Even if the fort isn't open, I think this is the best place in SF to show visitors the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Dylan C.

description:
Worth the drive to Fort Point. 

Easy access and free parking. Photo opportunities are abound. Glad we did it.
author: Clarence E.

description: Semi-secret alternative to the vista point above. This place puts you at sea-level, underneath the bridge. You will get splashed on a windy day.
author: CM P.

description:
A+ location to snag a photo with the Golden Gate Bridge! My tour guide from Painted Ladies Tour Company (highly recommend) brought us here. You get a clear and unobstructed view of the Golden Gate that is fairly close up. Walk on the small pier to take photos from different angles. 

If you're wanting to see the GG without crossing the bridge (and thus paying the fee), bookmark Fort Point. Lots of bicyclists pedaled from the marina/Crissy Field area to enjoy the view!
author: Katie U.

description:
Fort Point is one of those places that many people discover by accident or word of mouth.  But now the actual "Fort" is open to the public in its full historical glory.

It's a photographer's dream and the guides explain the significance of the structure which was built to protect the bay and city.  The old cannons and even cannot balls are still there to see.  If you go up to the top level there are magnificent views of the surrounding area - but if you're wearing a hat, hang onto it.  The winds are swirling and powerful on the best days and really cold during the winter.  It gives a reminder of what it was life for our armed fores who lived at and staffed the Fort when it was active.

This was my first time being able to actually enter and tour the Fort.  It certainly is a throwback to another time and well worth the trip.
author: Evan F.

description:
Looking for a place to get even closer pictures of the Golden Gate Bridge!?... look no further! Fort Point is the place to be.

Here are a few reasons why I believe this place is so damn amazing: 

It has free parking!
It has unique views of the golden gate bridge!
It is only a few steps to the beach 

I have been here several times and find something else to love about it.

Whether you're here for a bike ride, a picnic or sightseeing, this place has it all and its all free!

Just get here early.

I suggest bringing a backpack, comfortable shoes and your best digital camera as you'll want to take tons of pictures.  

I happened to be here during the Memorial Day Holiday which was also the Golden Gate Bridge's Birthday!

It was simply beautiful.  I could not have asked for better weather.

Even on a foggy day, this place is well worth the trek. 

I'll be back for sure for more adventures. 

Pics will be posted shortly...
author: Arnel D.

description: A great spot for watching Golden Gate Bridge with pacific oceans . Less crowded than other Vista points so you can relax and take photos instead of rushing and standing on queues to get clicked at the perfect spot. Also it was free parking so you won't spend extra money.
author: Nishant M.

description: First tip is bring a jacket! Plenty of free parking and more parking in the back. Just keep driving and don't try to fight for parking just because you see someone leaving or an empty spot in the front. People go here to look at the Golden Gate Bridge from the bottom view, surfing, crabbing, watch the sunset, running/hiking... etc. I also saw two couples taking their wedding photos inside the building, which I thought was totally awesome. The building is historical and free admission. Remember to go on the roof top.
author: John N.

description:
Such a great location to view the golden gate bridge. There is free parking, but it's just too crowded so we paid in one of the parking spaces, which was pretty cheap. 

There are so many people who come to take pictures, but there is plenty of space so no need to get frustrated if you see a large crowd. I love the view here and the bridge is so clear. It's so iconic that my sister and I had to take pictures.

It's a great way to walk around, enjoy the outdoors, and have the best view.
author: Anh L.

description:
5 star view!! But it's getting too crowded here and hard to park even for a few minutes.

The under the bridge view is well worth it though!

There is also a nice pier next to it and a tiny coffee hut which was never open.. definitely a must check out!

It's closed after sunset!
author: Deebs M.

description: Free and fascinating history. We were intending to stop by just for a walk-around and photos on our way to Ocean Beach, but a friendly ranger approached us and was full of funny, enlightening stories. The photos and views probably still are the highlights.
author: Carl B.

description: A very prestigious and Historical Landmark here in the Bay Area! Me and my wife ended up hiking Yesterday all over the area! It was a perfect day for a hike in San Francisco too! I would most definitely recommend this place to all my friends and family who love adventure and excitement while also getting a Brief history lesson about our home the Bay Area before a lot of us were even born!
author: Lamont J.

description: I am glad I was there. Wonderful photo opportunity. Do come before 9AM. It can get crowded after.
author: Jacky C.

description: Perfect place to view the golden gate bridge and intake the beautiful pacific ocean fresh air and nice scenic views. The fort itself is another additional gem, lots of nice historical things to see and on the second and third level there theses little window spots with amazing views of the golden gate bridge and the ocean . But the top is where the view is at! You can see a majority of the bay and you get these fresh ocean breeze, which is like a perfect little get away from the busy city, it is a tourist location but when I went with my bf on a Sunday and it actually wasn't that packed and we got to enjoy a lot of the nice views without being too distracted by tourists. Definitely will be back again.
author: Maybeline C.

description: San Francisco is just a wonderful place but I think going for a walk along the ocean and a wonderful view of the Golden Gate Bridge just can't get any better then that
author: Daisy D.

description:
Fort Point is one of those historical monuments that never shot its cannons in battle. That being said, it's still quite the impressive military fort that was in charge of protecting the entrance to the San Fransisco harbor and the heart of California in retrospect. 

As part of my visit to the Golden State Bridge, I stopped here as part of a recommendation of a friend. I was glad I did too because the fort was filled will historical facts and literature. Touring the fort was impressive and what struck me the most, was the fact that individuals actually called this for their homes for a while. My hat goes off to those individuals because just living there would of been quite a feat. I learned two things, it sure gets cold at the fort and the winds blew like they had somewhere to go in a hurry. 

I learned that the seacoast fort is not only used for tourism these days, but also for education and teachers can scheduled study trips here. As an educator, I fined that just grand. Also, the views from the fort were outstanding. Oh yes, if you go all the way to the top of the fort, wear something warm and keep a hold onto your hat or else you may find it floating away on the Pacific Ocean..
author: Jack M.

description:
Hidden gem! Perfect place to get a picture with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background. 

Neat fort to explore as well. Parking seemed to be easy. A little less known spot and it's free to enter!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Its FREE!
Its got lots of great photo ops and beautiful views.
Its fun to wander around.  
Its got limited parking...so get there early, or late in the day.  
Its also the future location of Star Fleet Headquarters.  Or at least part of it.  

Live long, and prosper!
author: Chun P.

description: This is truly a hidden gem in San Fran, and one of the best ways to avoid all the tourist to view the Golden Gate Bridge! The views are stunning and extremely unique, and there is so much history to learn at Fort Point. Bonus...parking and site are all free!
author: Keisha K.

description:
Brr, it was cold here.

One of the tourists of our party wanted to see under the Golden Gate Bridge. They seemed to be happy with the view even though there was a fence blocking directly underneath it.

The restrooms were fine as far as a public park location was concerned.
author: Jeff L.

description:
You need to visit this if you are in SF - full stop.

I was walking in the general direction of the bridge and ended up under it rather than on it. I figure I would  go all the way and here is For Point nestled under the bridge. What a wonderfully preserved fort from the 1800's and it is truly a living monument. You can climb the steep spiral stairs up to the roof - walk the powder magazines - see some exhibits and recreated rooms as they were during the 17th century. 

The saddest part is I spoke to  some SF residents and they have never been! It's free - it isn't crowded! Go for a nice walk and see some history.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Great and historic vantage point at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge... I really do recommend you visit Fort Point and take time to walk around it and read up on some of the history. The views are great no matter how foggy or clear a day you get. Parking is ample but you can usually find a spot. There are scheduled tours of Fort Point but I like walking it on my own and the different stairways from iron and sketchy to concrete and windy. You get it all at the Fort.

Make sure to get to the top level and marvel at the archways of the Golden Gate as well as the gun turrets spread about. It's crazy to think that was the defensive stronghold guarding the Bay. You cant beat the views. It's just amazing. From downstairs by Hopper's Hands to upstairs on the top level, it's a festival for the eyes. You can see the city from Fort Point or look out towards the ocean and even the massive iron works that make up the bottom part of the Golden Gate. It's beautiful. All of it... Make sure you go next time you're in the City. You'll be glad you did.
author: Chuck D.

description: A really great spot in SF--it's free, it's fun, and the views are amazing. Fort Point is a Civil War fort located just below the Golden Gate Bridge. It's really beautiful, and parts have been set up to look as they would have when it was in use. If you go up to the fourth floor, you get an amazing perspective of the Golden Gate Bridge, plus views of the Bay and Alcatraz. If you don't want to climb that many steps, you can peek out of the tiny windows on the other floors. It is usually freezing and quite windy, so dress accordingly.
author: Dara M.

description:
FREE parking. Easy to find with google maps.
Great views, able to see WHOLE Golden Gate Bridge, even the Altracaz Island. 
Lots of people use this route to exercise. - people even run up and touch "hopper's hands" on the fence Lol. (sorry no pic but maybe someone else took pics of it).
Good fresh air. It is chilly even if it's sunny out. 
Able to hike/walk up and across the bridge since there are stairs/trails up to it. 
People come here to fish too. 
Bathrooms available. 

See pics.
author: Chau N.

description:
Three stars for the fort in general, six stars for the candlelight tour.

The fort is cool and hosts several interesting events throughout the year.

The Living History Day (usually the last Saturday in January) is great, with volunteers in period costume and live period bands.

The best part is the candlelight tours in the winter. I've been three times. Each different and each amazing!
author: Menlo K.

description: I like it. It's stimulating, well preserved, interesting and ironically peaceful and scenic. Beautiful space, sublime in its feel, reminiscient of Boullée like illustrations of the cavernous voluminous, classically staid but an ironically unstaid elegant version of. A joy to visit. Recommended.
author: Juls C.

description: Great historical spot with amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the City skyline. Amazing places for pictures.
author: E. H.

description: The interesting thing about over here is their is some all white projects near bye that know one in the city of SF knows about wierd
author: Iz F.

description: Beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Every time we visit, we stop by.  You can get amazing pictures here, be sure to stop by.
author: Anna B.

description: We came here for engagement pictures, because that's one of the outstanding spots in SF. Parking was not so bad. But the strong wind was horrible. Such a nice view, it worth everything. There's some restrictions for shooting, make sure to read it before. Such a historic and amazing spot that attracts a lot of tourists. Love i
author: Karmen S.

description:
In the many times that I have visited the Golden Gate Bridge, I always try to find parking at the GGB Pavilion ($1/hour) or Vista Point (free). Both lots are always crowded. However, during my most recent visit, the parking lot for GGBP was super packed and I came across this friendly gentleman who directed me to park below at Fort Point. 

Fort Point is less than a five minute drive from GGBP and it has ample parking along the bay of SF. Parking is free and the bathroom lines down here are way shorter, too.

Not a lot of people know about this hidden view point of the Golden Gate Bridge so the crowd is smaller. 

Fort Point offers a lower view of the GGB, where you can look up and see the bridge. Only issue is you can't easily access the bridge to make the trek across from this location.

I saw a lot of people biking and picnicking around Fort Point. You can see the SF skyline from here on a clear day and the view is gorgeous!

If you have visited GGB many times, definitely check out Fort Point since it offers a different perspective! Enjoy!
author: Minh-An C.

description: Awesome views of Golden Gate Bridge coupled with an informative and interesting historical building. And all for free! Highly recommend making a stop here as you will learn some history and see unique views of the Golden Gate Bridge you can't get anywhere else!
author: Becky V.

description:
A view of the Golden Gate Bridge like you've never seen it before. 

Fort Point is full of history. The building itself has different areas for you to explore and read up on its original use. However, the best part of the experience is going to the roof and standing underneath the Golden Gate Bridge. The views are unreal and truly breathtaking. Side note: It's super windy!! 

The best place to take photos are up on the top of the building. If you go to the corner closest to the bridge and the waters edge, you can get some great snapshots from different low angles to capture the bridge directly behind you. It's picture perfect!!
author: Courtney O.

description:
Fort Point is an absolute hidden gem in SF. Situated at the base of the Golden Gate Bridge, you can't help but be captivated by the area's rich history, which dates back to the late 1700s during Spanish occupation of the region. Even though I did not go inside,  judging by the other reviews it sounds like an awesome (and best of all free!) experience. 

Aside from the fort itself, just coming for the view alone is worth the trip. I'm Bay Area born and bred. Yet I'm ashamed to say that I only found out about this place recently. Once you arrive, you'll be treated to a breathtaking panoramic view of the City, the Bridge, and Alcatraz. Be sure to take a moment to sit on the rocks and soak it all in.

Feeling ambitious? Bring your running gear too! The Marina to Fort Point route is quite popular among locals. Start at Marina Green Park and make your way across Crissy Field. When you finally arrive at Fort Point, give Hopper's Hands a high-five before turning around. There's even a placard for your canine friend if he came along on the adventure. Yes, it's a strange tradition. But embrace it without question, you must.
author: Darren L.

description:
I've never heard about this place. My friend and I've walked from the Palace of Fine Arts to Crissy Field, and all the way down I was rewarded with Fort Point. The California Historical Landmark is a Civil War-era brick fort that lies directly below the Golden Gate Bridge. This is a great place to visit if you're a history buff- roam the fort and see the cannons and sleeping quarters.

I'm not a history buff, but I do appreciate the history behind the place. The best part for me and for most people would be the amazing view of Golden Gate Bridge. It makes for great pictures! It's quite windy at the top though. The admission is free, so there are no excuses on not coming here!
author: Helen H.

description:
I wish we had more time at Fort Point but it was one of the stops on our tour.  There was parking for our bus and availability for cars too on a weekday afternoon.  The location offers great views of the Golden Gate Bridge.  We spent more of our time taking photos and enjoying the view.  There were a handful of people fishing too so it was fun to see them too.  I liked that it wasn't very busy and we could get some shots of the Golden Gate.

If we had more time, I would have liked to explore the Fort more and also the surrounding areas.  We walked briefly to check inside before heading out to take photos of the bridge.  There's a small bookstore and restrooms close to the Fort.
author: Violet P.

description:
Was there on 4th of July but the weather and temperature of that day was chilly & foggy, few clouds moved in with strong wind after lunch hour.  Was there for an hour or so didn't have enough time to explore more surrounding area as 5 Uber missed to pick us up there (they said they couldn't get to us as there was no route on the map to get to the Fort Point building) and then we missed the ferry ride back home.  

On that day lots of people came in with their picnic cooler or BBQ equipment and set up the tent by the bridge.  It's a happy place for holiday gathering no matter it was a good weather or not, people just wanna had fun and enjoy the day there.

San Francisco is a very beautiful & fun city, we will come back to visit again soon.
author: Cou. P.

description:
Came here when I was younger for crabbing and fishing. There were locals but not the numbers there are currently. 

Before there were always a place to park, now they put meters in crissy field it's no more. The area has more tourist due to amount of tour buses and bicyclist and even Scoot. Horrible place for locals, just a tourist trap.
author: M C.

description: Great spot to see the bridge up close. Also to view Alcatraz from afar. We literally visited around 4-5 view points and this one was, BY FAR, the best one. Even has garden areas and trails to walk through and learn interesting facts about the area and history of the Fort and Battery. Remember to take money to pay the parking!!
author: Michelle M. C.

description: An excellent spot to view the bridge. There are all sorts of paths for walking that offer different vantage points for the GG. If you want you can even walk across the bridge.
author: Jenifer N.

description:
Review #100 why I hella love the Bay (yes, "hella" bc Bay Area / NorCal).

To see why, visit California Historical Landmark #82: Fort Point (registered under its official name in 1794 "Castillo De San Joaquín").

On a clear day, three bridges and sweeping views of the Bay Area are visible from Fort Point: Marin in the North; Alcatraz, Angel Island, & the East Bay across the water; and to the far right, across Crissy Field, you'll spot San Francisco's famous skyline. 

Strategically located at the entrance of San Francisco Bay, Fort Point was one of three coastal defense posts built during the Civil War-era. To preserve the stunning masonry, an impressive steel arch was built to support the Golden Gate Bridge's roadway, rather than demolishing the fort during the bridge's construction. 

Such a fun place to explore for all ages. Take a tour. Or not. If you're up for a short hike, trek to the newly renovated Golden Gate Bridge Pavilion by heading towards the Warming Hut. The trailhead will be on your right, follow the stair path and signs up to the Golden Gate Bridge Plaza.

Directions to Fort Point:
Follow Marina Blvd along the shoreline and through Crissy Field, or follow the main road and the Presidio Promenade along Lincoln Blvd, take Long Ave all the way down to the fort.

Tips:
* Tours and cannon-loading demonstration are offered Friday to Sunday, 10am to 5pm;
* Maintained restrooms are available outside;
* Dogs are allowed on leash on Fort Point lands (but not inside the actual fort);
* Between March and October, you'll likely spot migrating whales and seal pups (and surfers year-round);
* Bring sufficient outerwear - it's windy down here & fog is present during summer months / winter days, eventually burning off by noon, only to return again in the evening. 

Pro-Tip:
* Don't forget to high five Hopper's Hands!

Have you noticed numerous joggers putting their hands against the chain-link fence at the farthest end of Fort Point and wondered why? 

There's a small inspirational placard mounted next to the "No Trespassing" sign where the sidewalk ends. 

The current placard is painted black & orange in honor of the SF Giants. Ken Hopper is a Golden Gate Bridge ironworker who's been called to rescue over 30 bridge jumpers in the last 32 years. "Hoppers Hands" is a life-sized tracing of Ken own hands.

Below the sign, a few feet off the ground, is a smaller placard, with a pair of doggy paw prints for your four-legged friend to join in on the tradition.

So whatcha waiting for? Throw on your puff coat and venture off into the Presidio!
author: Geminyna J.

description: Such a cool spot to visit in SF. I would always see it driving by but never made the stop, now I finally did and would recommend it to all visitors and locals. Not only has a cool history but the location is so neat at the base of the bridge! Bring a jacket though cause it's super windy and cool here. Feel like a kid again here wanting to explore every room.
author: Ranee W.

description: I can say that this the far most un obstructive view of the golden bridge as long as the sky is clear :) we got there when the bridge has a lot of fog so we didn't get  a clear view. But if the sky is clear, visit this scenic point :)
author: Jeralyn R.

description:
WHOA BABY!!!!

For a long time I wondered where do people go to take pictures of this particular view but I finally found it. 

Magnificent!!!!

The bridge looks enormous from here.

There is a lot of parking A+ for that. There are surfers there so everything fits just right.
author: Jannie M.

description: Great place to take pictures of the bridge. Always a ton of people there so parking won't be easy. Be careful on the road that leads up to Fort point. It's a small road with bicyclists and people walking.
author: RJ D.

description:
Funny thing that I've never noticed this landmark until one day I needed to circle the parking lot as I was making an exit. I've been visiting here for years and seriously knew nothing about it. As curious as I was, I parked the car and walked in. I was greeted by someone at the entrance and was told there was no fee to enter. It was his pitch to persuade me to take a tour and it worked!

I'll not get into the history behind Fort Point as it is part of the experience. If you love history like myself it's worth the time. The view itself is enough to lure you in. Bring a camera and take photos of ships entering and exiting the gate. Catch an underside angle of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Gene B.

description:
Great view of the Golden Gate Bridge!

The view of the bridge here is definitely more beautiful during daytime than at night just because you could see its architecture more in-depth.

It may be traffic to get here so come before or after rush hour. Parking spaces are also very limited. Watch out for bikers and joggers.
author: Aj C.

description:
Great hidden treasure of the Bay Area .. One of SF historic sites 
Loved all the pictures of our service men from the 1800's , loved the display of their actual living quarters ...wow I'm sure they where freezing living so close to the mouth of the bay ( of course no GG till 1936) 
We went on a very foggy day , so absolutely NO view  of bridge ( fog horns ) except from inside the Fort ... Very very interesting place , played a role in Alfred Hitchcocks Vertigo ( when the main female character jumped in the water , she jumped from one of the fort Windows , which are welded shut now ) .
We've been to SF at least 8 times ( maybe 10 ) this 1st discovering this Fort .   Our next trip we will b back on a sunny day !!!
author: Debra S.

description: Fantastic place to visit in SF.  Great historical site and such a great view of the water and the bridge.  Free admission and a fun place to visit for an hour or so.  It is very cold and windy, and be prepared to climb quite a few stairs to make it to the top.  Worth it though!
author: D C.

description:
This review is for the super-hard-to-snag "Candlelight Tour."

They only give the tour a handful of times a year, the tour is free of charge, and you must make reservations.  They limit each tour to 25 people.

Ok, once you get there, it's pitch black dark and we weren't sure where exactly to go wait.  We used our phones as flashlights to find the front door.  TIP: There is only one way in and one way out of Fort Point... that's where you go for the tour.  It's not just a door, it's a sallyport! (Fun word I learned on the tour.)

The park ranger gave us real lanterns with real candles.  I was expecting battery operated flames, so the real candle was a nice touch.  The lanterns are beautiful and help set the mood.  He took us to all the exhibits and told us about each room we visited.  One thing we got to do which he said only people on the candlelight tour get to experience is, going inside the fort's jail cells.  

We learned about the history of Fort Point, how it got built, why it was built,. what went on inside the complex, who lived here, what their duties were, what happened over the years, etc. etc.  A very thorough history verging on information overload.

FUN FACT: Fort Point is over 90% original.  (It never saw combative action, so, unlike forts on the East Coast, it's all pretty original.)

At the end of the tour we were given time to explore and enjoy the views from the roof.

It is very dark.  If you are afraid of the dark, stick close with your friends.  I felt bad for the park ranger having to go blow out all the lanterns all by himself after the tour was over.  

It's a very cool tour and I recommend it to anyone who's interested in San Francisco and/or military history.
author: Chloe M.

description: This is a wonder place to walk and enjoy great views of the Golden Gate Bridge.  It can be very cold and windy.  This was originally a fort during the civil war.  It feels like you are stepping back it time.
author: Sheila F.

description:
Okay, so this is one of the best places to photograph the Golden Gate Bridge.

However, there was actually a military base here long ago, and part of what's here is preserved for the sake of history.

I'm sure most people will walk past it to get to the bridge, and never notice a part of history that is perhaps, more important to the U.S.A.  It's just a lot more quiet since the 20th century has passed.
author: Nobuyuki S.

description: Really the only way to get here is with a car.  I didn't have trouble parking.  The view of the Golden Gate bridge and the city of Fisco is worthy of a visit on its own.  Most people want a higher vantage point making this a less crowded place to compete for parking and selfies with yourself only.
author: Darrell K.

description: Super awesome free spot to see one of America's greatest engineering feats. Hardly any people around and easy to find. Took tons of pictures and the weather was amazing. If you don't  have time to drive across the bridge and want a quick amazing view, this is it.
author: Casey S.

description:
My friend wanted to check out the Golden Gate Bridge, and having been around the area pretty often, I never really found the thrill in looking at this landmark - to be honest, I actually preferred the new Bay Bridge.

Until I checked out Fort Point...

I didn't know this area existed until I yelped it. I thought that to see the Golden Gate Bridge up close, you just drive up to Crissy Fields or simply walk up next to it. But boy was I wrong. Fort Point is this hell of a gem that's free and open to the public (until 5pm) and on certain days. Apparently, the structure is pretty much a remnant of an old Fort that you can explore around.

Since we only had about 10 minutes, my friend and I immediately ran up three flights of stairs to see the bridge up close. And boy was it magnificent! You really are RIGHT next to the bridge, so close that you can almost touch it. I definitely never knew that Fort Point existed for the public to check out. Definitely come early to get as many breathtaking photos and possible and enjoy the view.

All in all, I enjoyed Fort Point and I'll come again to explore every nook and cranny.

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: We enjoyed our visit to Fort Point, which is under the Golden Gate Brige.  Expect high winds, but also expect stunning views when it isn't foggy.  This is also a great historical site with some informative documentaries and presentations.
author: Tom T.

description: This place is probably more interesting than the bridge itself. Easier parking too. First off, there's an incredible view of the waves, city, and bridge from the front of the fort. Once inside there are many floors and rooms to explore. The top of the fort is a must to get those incredible pictures with the bridge in the background.
author: Eddie C.

description: What incredible views! The workers were also very nice & knowledgeable. Ive lived out here my whole life and just now found this spot. Met a lot of nice tourists from different countries. Had an incredible time, the kids are already asking to to back!
author: Dee L.

description:
The glorious worm's-eye view of the Golden Gate Bridge alone is reason enough to endure through the high traffic to get there! The location right under the bridge on the coast is beautiful and serene, making it a prime location for cyclists and runners alike to come all the way down. Be ready for the windy and chilly atmosphere though. The restrooms were very clean and the encompassing vibe of the area being south of the actual touristy bridge part is so calming and breathtaking. 

Overall it is out of the way and you might hit traffic coming from west of Lincoln, but it is worth it for the remarkable photo ops! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description: Wow! The sun came out and showed us why this is the best point for Golden Gate Bridge viewing. Just immaculate and I did not want to leave. I probably took about a 100 pictures and kid you not all with different backgrounds. Plus point a whale family gave us a show while we listened to the wave crashing. Make sure you find time but go on a sunny day.
author: N And N K.

description: Great view of Golden Gate Bridge! We parked our car at the "welcome Golden Gate Bridge " site before crossing the bridge.  We saw a sea lion swimming by the pier . What a great surprise !
author: Cindy G.

description:
This is a great place for sightseeing and photo-ops for the Golden Gate Bridge!!

I came here before 12 noon and just took in the beautiful view and breeze. This is also a historic point and the exhibits are free to the public (but you can put it a donation at the front to keep the park available for everyone).

Once you go past the building, you can walk through the hallways and read up on the history of the soldiers and view some mini exhibits. If you wish to see the lighthouse, take the stairs and go all the way up. You can see where the cannons used to be and also get a nice view of Alcatraz Island.

TIP: When you're on your way, you will notice a small lot for parking. This requires a fee. Instead, continue down the road towards Marine Dr. because there is free parking at the entrance of Fort Point.
author: Eva L.

description:
When I was researching the Golden Gate Bridge and where would be good places to take pictures, a lot of people mentioned Fort Point. So of course I made JQ take me here when we went to go see the GGB. Built by the US Army in 1861, Fort Point is the only brick fort on the West Coast of the US. A classic example of early 19th century coastal fortifications, it was used to defend the SF harbor against invasion by foreign powers. In the 1930s engineers used it as their HQ when building the GGB and in 1970 Congress made Fort Pointe a National Historic Site.

It was really easy to find, they have free parking, and apparently people also perform Shakespeare plays here. There was a rehearsal for Hamlet going on when we were there. Definitely wear something warm because it gets really windy there! But it was cool to walk around and see the officers' and enlisted men's quarters. There's a lighthouse and a small gift shop there as well. And of course great view of the GGB from underneath :)
author: Esther K.

description: This was the first stop to experience S.F. We came here early on Monday, before they opened so we found parking easily. While we waited we explored the areas around. People were fishing and we even saw a sea lion swimming near by.Once they opened we started doing a self-guided tour, The guided tour wasn't scheduled until 2pm. This place is awesome! There were a few people at that time and we got to experience the whole fort. We took some awesome pictures at the very top. If you want to know some cool history of this fort and have some great photo ops please come here. This place is free with free parking and is such a historic monument.
author: Mari S.

description:
So this is where we accidentally found the absolute best view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

We were actually trying to get to Chrissy Field, but we took a wrong turn somewhere & saw there was a road, so we kept driving, and we saw a few people crabbing off a little pier. So we parked the car and walked out to the end, and there it was:

A completely perfect view of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz Island, and the San Francisco city skyline. All of which, may I add, start to glitter & sparkle once the sun begins to set (about 15-20 mins before sunset). If you want to take a panorama picture, this has to be the best place to do it. The day we were there, there were no clouds, no fog, and no obstructions to our gorgeous view. Just the occasional seagull & barking sea lion. I took so many beautiful pictures here!

I wish we had found Fort Point sooner, because there was a National Parks Service shop & cafe, and a few signs that describe the historical importance of this fort. But we only had enough time to catch the sunset! The park buildings closed at 5pm. Maybe next time we will make enough time to explore!
author: JoAnna D.

description: Fort point!!  One of two civil era forts in the Bay Area.  You'll never guess where the other one is.   It's open now Fr-sun and open 6 days a week in summer.  Be sure to check it out.   Catch a ranger program if you can.  Best of all, catch the candle light tour.  One big hint:  always bring extra layers.  It's cold and windy in there.
author: Marcus K.

description: For fantastic views of the Golden Gate Bridge from below, this free landmark at the end of the Presidio is worth the effort.  It's rich with history, an old military fort used to protect the bay from invasion during the Civil War.  You can explore the grounds and fort at no cost.  Just be warned, I visited in July and I visited in September and both times it was windy and cold.  If you come in July, the fog is so thick you can't see the bridge anyway.  Bring warm layers before coming here.
author: Anthony G.

description: Another obligatory photo op is of the famous Golden Gate Bridge. After watching Vertigo many moons ago, the Misters and I sought out this location since it had a cool closer view of the bridge. We took pics here on our last visit, so we of course had to do bring the LO.  It still an awesome place!  You have to go through the Presidio and follow the signs to Fort Point.  There's a parking lot and restrooms, which is a plus for families!
author: Rochelle R.

description: Love catching crab here! I go quite often and never leave empty handed.... November is a lil slow, as the year passes they get bigger..
author: Craig M.

description:
Joseph Strauss the Chief Engineer for the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge had the foresight to save this wonderful fort, and now it can be enjoyed, at no charge, by people today.  

I found the fort fascinating for many reasons.  I really felt I was stepping back into history, and as I walked around the interior. I wondered if my California ancestors who fought in the Civil War ever walked where I was walking.  Looking up, it is interesting to see the art of the master brick masonry from the Civil War period framed by the underside of the Art Deco Golden Gate Bridge that opened in 1937.

I was disappointed that when I went the upper floors of the fort were closed for railing repairs; I had visualized an interior photo. Oh well, it close by and I can go back, take the photo.

The fort interior is cold even when it is warm outside.
author: Terry T.

description:
One of my favorite places in San Francisco. Fort Point is gorgeous; originally one of the towers of the bridge was going to be here, but after the architect saw it in person he redesigned the bridge to save the fort. 

Other cool things about the Fort Point:

1) It is a civil war fort. Take a minute and think about how crazy that is.
2) Each brick was made on site specifically for the fort. Take a look at some of the arches and you will see some incredible work. Beautiful.
3) The BEST place in all of the city to watch the blue angels; they fly right over you (but you need to climb to the top of the fort, what is wrong with all you people that just stay in the parking lot?!). Actually, you know what, never mind. You didn't read that. I prefer having that secret to myself. Crissy Field is the best place, I'm sure. Go there. 
4) There are daytime and candlelight tours here, and a cannon loading demonstration for the kids (No, they don't actually fire the cannon, but it's still fun, and they can get a certificate for assisting).
5) It is a great spot to take pictures. On top right under the bridge, near the gorgeous arches, in the doorways of where the rows of rooms are (there are no doors and you can get some great pictures of people peeking out from the different rooms along the way), on the large stone stairs (each step weighs 1,000 pounds!). 
6) Yes, a scene from Vertigo was filmed here. But of all the things that make this place cool I think it ranks towards the bottom.

Other things to know: It is cold and windy no matter the day. Hopefully you know the city well enough to expect that, but if not bring a jacket for pete's sake! 
It's FREE. There is a donation box at the front, but the fort is free to enter and explore. AND the tours are all free! Even the candlelight one, you just have to make a reservation. 
Right now it is only open Friday through Sunday, 10am-5pm. 

Basically, if you haven't been here yet you need to fix that ASAP because you are missing out. I think you can tell from my review that I have been on multiple tours; they are 100% worth it. And I'm saying that as someone that does not usually enjoy tours.
author: Kari E.

description:
"The Pride of the Pacific."  I've always seen this place whenever we head over and walk across the Golden Gate Bridge.  Heck, I've even taken a few photos in front of this place as a kid and even as a teenager.  It wasn't until one of my more recent trips where I got to venture inside to see what it was all about.  I didn't even know this place could be toured!

My uncle decided to drop off my two gal friends and I here while he ran some errands.  I don't think he anticipated how nerdy we can get because we took quite a long tour of this place and soaked up all the rich history.   Fort Point was built during the American Civil War.  Starting construction in 1853 at the height of the Gold Rush and finishing in 1861, Fort Point was mastered to protect San Francisco but was never once actually used in any sort of battle.  Inside this massive architecture is a maze of windy shallow stairs, canons, rooms with giant informative posters behind pixie glass, and the most amazing views on the rooftops.  

We also got a weird cheap thrill here [not that kind, pervs!].  None of us had research this place since we didn't even know the name of this fort until we got here.  This place is kinda chilling!  I swear we all entered this room together but the three of us all got split up.  I was reading about women's role in the Fort and I thought my friend was next to me.  All three of us had the same experience but in different rooms of the base.  It was weird and it took fifteen minutes to locate everyone.  Cell phone reception was bad here, okay?  :P

Anyways, Fort Point is a cool place to visit and it's definitely an interesting place to soak up some history for free.  Kudos for defending San Francisco, Fort Point!
author: Joyce W.

description:
In the shadow of the most famous bridge in the world, Fort Point can easily be overlooked. Fortunately, we took notice, and entered the fort's interior for a modest donation.

We were immediately paid back with fascinating views of the underbelly of the Golden Gate Bridge. After climbing three flights of steps to the top of the fort, we encircled its paint-splattered parapet. The superstructure of the bridge soared above and the fort's courtyard and arched fortifications lay below.

Descending a granite spiral staircase, we meandered through the impenetrable red brick fortress, and peered out of its rusted iron casements. The enlightening museum revealed that Fort Point was the only brick artillery fort ever built on the west coast.

Ironically, the fort itself had to be defended from destruction, during the building of the Golden Gate Bridge. Chief bridge engineer Joseph Strauss saved it, as "a fine example of the mason's art", by designing a special arch to straddle the fort.  

Today, Fort Point survives as one of the finest Civil War Period masonry structures in America, and endures as a lookout post in the shadow of the most famous bridge in the world.
author: Joe R.

description:
On a whim, I decided to go on a Go Car Tour and amongst the advised sites to see, Fort Point was one of the top historical areas to visit. 

Upon arriving to Fort Point, all I could see was a huge arch ascending above the bay waters. 

There it was. The Golden Gate Bridge in all its glory.

I have never been so close to the Golden Gate Bridge besides driving across it. When walking across this bridge, even with that, you truly can't appreciate the architecture and design of the bridge as much as you would if you visited Fort Point.

Fort Point was constructed during the American Civil War in 1853 and finished in 1861. Its architecture was the only one of this nature that was built West of the Mississippi during this time. It was originally meant to protect the San Francisco bay during the height of the Gold Rush and even though its cannons never fired a single shot for war, it still served as an important military base. 

These days, it is recognized for its rich history. On October 16, 1970, Fort Point became a National Historic Site. 

There's a museum open to the public in which it showcases the many different uses that the fort has had over the years. 

Personally, I think it's a great area to visit. The views of the bridge are absolutely breathtaking and the lull of the bay waters are calming and perfect for fishing. You can even catch people surfing here.

Wonderful place to enjoy when discovering more of San Francisco and its origins!
author: Ann S.

description: I'm from SoCal and have been to San Francisco many times over the years, but never made it to the Presidio.  This time we did.  The North Fort was fascinating.  What a great surprise.  A big old mega-brick fort loaded with cannons.  Built after the Gold Rush on a spot carved out of the rock to replace an old Spanish fort and spanned overhead by the newer Golden Gate bridge in an effort to spare it as a landmark.  We had a lot of fun climbing around the spiral staircases, and on the roof.  Beautiful views of the Bay and the Pacific from there.  Very cool.  I wish there were more places like this in CA.
author: James N.

description: Been making trips to the bay for years and never knew about this place. Lots of fun facts and history about San Francisco and the building of the Golden Gate bridge. A must see. And it's free!!
author: Ngaolia C.

description:
I've recently moved back to the Bay Area after a year in Portland - which I'm really, really (REALLY) happy about. As an avid Hitchcock fan and lover of "Vertigo," I wanted to finally check out Fort Point. 

Turns out this is a pretty rad - and free! - spot to go on a sunny Sunday. I even found parking without any issues. You can roam around the fort as you'd like. Most of the rooms are empty, but some have been furnished to recreate how they originally looked. 

The view on top of the roof is pretty remarkable. The fort is RIGHT under the Golden Gate. On one side you get a view of Baker Beach and Marin, while on the other you get a view of the SF skyline. It's super super windy, mind you. My body was being blown back, so I'd be careful bringing your kiddos up here. Also, maybe consider bringing a hairbrush for after your visit - I looked like a real mess after coming down off the roof.

I wouldn't overlook Fort Point just because it's a touristy spot - a visit here will remind you why you live in this amazing city.
author: K M.

description:
There are two easy ways to see the underside of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Either take a cruise under the bridge, or visit Fort Point.  The advantage of Fort Point is that it's free and you get a lot closer to the bridge.

For those of you who are history buffs, Fort Point is a time capsule of the Civil War period.  There are many historical artifacts on display, including uniforms, medals, cannons and cannonballs.  You can also see where Civil War soldiers slept and learn what they ate.

Here's a tip: just as you enter the tunnel, look to your right.  There is a display which lists the activities, tours, and demonstrations for the day and their times.

Just think: they almost demolished Fort Point to build the Golden Gate Bridge.  Joseph Strauss wanted to spare the fort, which explains why there is a small arch here which precisely straddles Fort Point.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description:
Check out Fort Point, constructed over a 1794 defensive structure, this 1853 fort was one of over 30 built in the US though this is the only one that was built on the West Coast. 

This is a Gem , hidden by the Golden Gate Bridge , but think of it as a great destination if you want to park over at either the Marina Green or Crissy Field and hike over , !
author: Joseph A.

description:
Always saw this from atop the golden gate bridge and wondered what it was and how to get down there.

Did the SF Movie Tours and finally got that answered.

The view from this angle is stellar!!! 
Believe it or not, there was parking here on a SUNDAY!!!

It is SUPER cold and WINDY!!! 
Bring WINTER CLOTHES!!!

They also have tours at 11AM so I'm definitely coming back for that.
author: David W.

description: This is a hidden little treasure in the area. It's hard to get to if you don't have a car, so we took a Lyft to get there. The fort is pretty big and has a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge. It's a one of kind angle of the bridge from below.  We were there in the afternoon so the lighting was really nice for photos. There is quite a bit to see and read so make sure you give yourself enough time before closing.
author: Erin L.

description:

description:

Stay for the history.
author: Emily J.
