author: Da X.

description: The view of the Golden Gate Bridge was amazing. Ample parking and good place to bike .
author: Kaycee C.

description:
Getting married is a big thing.  The wedding itself may or may not be but the act of standing before God and everyone and vowing to stay with someone through poverty and ill health is filled with gravitas.  At 16 I broke up with a boyfriend who stood at my bedroom window proclaiming that he'd have asked me to marry him had I been two years older.  Then, when I finally got a marriage proposal (different guy) it happened in a crosswalk in Calistoga.  Not on bent knee either.  We were walking across the street.  So that moment was not weighty nor did it reflect the seriousness of the journey I was being asked to embark upon.  Don't let your marriage proposal be like this.  

A good marriage proposal, in my opinion, should be big and bold and make a statement about the life that you envision spending together; the only life I'm certain you get.  It should reflect that this is a huge journey you're asking someone to join you in.  Plan accordingly.  

What's this have to do with Fort Point, you ask?  It is atop Fort Point, in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge, that there exists what I believe to be the perfect location for a marriage proposal.  With the bay on one side, the ocean on another, the huge bridge looming, the salty air, and the city in the background you have every potential metaphor for the act of marriage available to each of your senses.  Get creative.  Indulge.  There's no wrong answers.  

And then, assuming children come later you can return to Fort Point with a story to tell.  Your children, especially if they're boys, will appreciate the opportunity to run around here.  Up steep stairways through multiple floors.  Down long, narrow, hidden hallways.  Had I taken my boys here when they were younger they'd have thought this the perfect location for hide and seek or tag though the latter might not be appreciated much by others or by the Park Service who oversees the whole thing.  

Entrance to the fort is free as is nearby parking right on the water's edge.  If you want to make it more of a journey, you can hike in from many different directions (Golden Gate Bridge, Crissy Field, Presidio).  Dogs aren't allowed and neither is food or drink though I imagine it wouldn't be too difficult to sneak in a split of champagne.  Go big or go home.  

Fort Point also has a lot of historical information at hand as well as cannons and powder kegs.  For me though, it's all about that rooftop.  Perhaps it will be the same for you.
author: Tracey A.

description: Beautiful place to view the bridge, visited last Saturday night for the Candlelight tour with Makoto as our enthusiastic guide. Thanks for the awesome night time historical experience, we will definitely be returning in the day time for the views! Can't believe we haven't been to this place until now.
author: Mingmei N.

description:
As an SF tourist and someone who hasn't been here in awhile... I appreciate any place that gives me a unique view of the city.
Such a beautiful spot to get lovely views of the Golden Gate Bridge.
Free parking and free admission... what's not to like?
When we came there was only one other group and us so I doubt that this place gets crowded.
Being right under the bridge is pretty cool and it's just nice being here.
Awesome spot for picture taking and just enjoying the sights.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Our Uber driver had no idea where this was and it was our first time so we went in a bit of a circle. BUT worth it-- Amazing spot for photos to see the bridge and the city! Use Maps to get there.
author: Katherine H.

description: Surprisingly minimal tourist traffic for such an amazing location.  Breathtaking views of the bridge, beach, Alcatraz, bay and city.  Bring the selfie stick!
author: Ed J.

description:
Is it even possible to have many words to say about this place? Because it'll take your breathe away. Absolutely jaw dropping. I love the Golden Gate Bridge and this view of it is without a doubt, the best. 

Parking is easy. And there's a lot of little walkways and paths to get here, or you can just drive down here. There isn't a bad view to be had and it's beautiful. 

Perfect on a sunny day and I would imagine just as perfect on a rainy day as well. 

Parking was $.50 a half hour up top!
author: Melanie R.

description: Lovely view on a sunny day in sf. Easy and free parking on a Wednesday. My pup and I had a great time walking to the bridge and hiking along the costal trail to baker beach!
author: Michelle H.

description:
I almost didn't go to Fort Point. What a shame that would've been. Fort Point is one of the best spots to enjoy views of the Golden Gate Bridge, not to mention the history! 

In my opinion, here is how you should take in Fort Point:

Don't be tempted to park too close to the fort. My advice is to park further away and walk along the rocks towards the fort. During your walk, take in the fresh air and breeze from the SF Bay. 

Walk through the entrance, stand in the middle of the hall and slowly do a 360. The grandeur of the hall is truly breathtaking. Once you've taken all that in, walk through each floor. Unlike others, don't rush through and climb to the top. Each floor has its own secrets - officers quarters, spiral staircases, secret corners, almost hidden windows with compartment views of the bay & bridge. 

After exploring, finally go to the roof and breathe. Here, you are up close and personal with the bridge. Walk under it, take some photos, get creative. Don't get too distracted by the bridge, albeit beautiful. Look around - the from that vantage point is beautiful! 

So glad I had a chance to visit Fort Point. Can't wait to come back!
author: Lily C.

description: One of the coolest spots in all of SF!  History, views and it feels like an insider's type of secret spot - awesome!  Fort Point provides a really awesome view of one of the world's wonders - The Golden Gate Bridge - from the underside!  Imagine long before the bridge was built, the entrance to the SF Bay needed defending from marauders, pirates and foreign enemies. Today, it's open to the public (FREE) to wander through and experience the civil war-era fort.  It's an amazing place to view the Golden Gate Bridge, look out over the Bay and look east toward the SF skyline...and of course Alcatraz!  I highly recommend Fort Point along with a nice walk up on to the GG Bridge.  In nice weather, there's nothing better! FIVE golden stars, thank you.
author: Patrick L.

description: This place was amazing. I have lived in the bay area for over 30 years and this is a great historic landmark. Great place for a walk and great views too !
author: Nick M.

description: Not as crowded as the other tourist destination to have a look at yhe bridge but damn this is worth the drive. Awesome place!
author: Andrew D.

description:
After enjoying a day in the city, we were headed up to Petaluma.  We had grabbed some fast food since we were starving and made our way down to Fort Point to enjoy the view while we ate our lunch.

I have always wanted to go here as I've heard the views are awesome.  We parked in the lot near the fort overlooking the city and the bay and enjoyed the view.  After finishing my food I asked if anyone wanted to scout out the fort.  Unfortunately I was the only person interested, so I set off alone.

Since I didn't want to keep everyone waiting, I immediately climbed the stairs to the top of the fort.  I was blown away by the view from the top.  I took it in quickly and snapped some photos before heading back down.

I definitely want to come back and enjoy this place at a more leisurely pace as there appeared to be a lot of signs and historical info that I didn't have time to take in.
author: Richard G.

description: Lovely view of the Golden Gate Bridge that every tourist should go to! Crissy Fields leads you directly to this, and then Fort Pointe leads directly to the walkway of the bridge itself.
author: Brian A.

description: Spooky and awesome. I dated a girl who was writing a futuristic sci-do story about this place. I really need to find out if she ever published. Anyway go here, explore, have fun!
author: Everybody S.

description:
FREE.  You can't hate on that.

Easy to get to on foot or bike.

We went here mainly for the AWESOME views of the GG bridge, so I can't really speak much for the history of Fort Point or the exhibits inside.  There's a small gift shop on the ground level with a nice selection for it's size.  

Please go here if you're obsessed with the bridge like I am.  Go to the very top and take a million pictures of it.  It's beautiful.
author: Allison L.

description: This place holds so much history right at the base of Golden Gate Bridge. It's awesome to look around and see original cannons and how gun powder barrels were stored. Some windows in the fort are opened to the bay. Its an amazing view. Tours are given or you can explore by yourself. Its a nice jog to the fort if you park along Chrissy Field and a fantastic view! Cant wait to go back.
author: Sandra G.

description: Just a beautiful place to absorb the views of The City. Make sure to take a walk on the pier. Fort Point Pier is still used for fishing & crabbing..
author: Peter F.

description:
Fort Point holds such an amazing view of the Bridge that should be viewed by all newcomers... unless of course the FOG is in the way. I swear, the Fog is a creature that terrorizes SF every day.

During October, it's said that they have ghost tours through the fort at night complete with lanterns and candles. I need to come back for that!
author: Leslie D.

description:
I must be on a Vertigo kick since I was just at the Legion of Honor as well. Hitchcock-blockers know that Fort Point is where a suicidal Kim Novak goes into the drink to be rescued by an obsessed Jimmy Stewart. I think the last time I was here I was in a daisy chain of Parkside Elementary School second-graders following Miss Gonzales. Oh, that was when I was 7... not last week. I know what you were thinking. Shame on you.

It's still very much worth a browse and a free tour if you can catch one. You'll find out it was built just before the Civil War as the only fort to ward off the enemy on the West Coast, whoever they may be. They never did come attack us, but what's left is a red-brick fortification with condo conversion possibilities. Walls are seven feet deep, bunk beds are big enough for two (sorta), and there's an extensive wine cellar with barrels of... oh wait, they're gunpowder kegs.

But what a view. Traipse up the three floors and take a gander at the Golden Gate Bridge from the underbelly. And sometimes the curators take advantage of the historical remnants of cannons and turrets and recreate the Civil War in the wide-open central courtyard. Only open Friday through Sunday, it's an easy stroll from Crissy Field where you can replenish at the Warming Hut. Oh and bring a jacket because it gets a tad brisk over there. A tad?... who am I kidding?
author: Ed U.

description: Stunning views of the Golden Gate Bridge from here! Visiting the Fort was an amazing experience. I got to see how soldiers lived years ago while fighting the enemy with cannons and all. They still have some of the cannon balls and even uniforms and bunk beds where they slept. The best thing is that it's FREE Admission for everyone!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Absolutely love this area!!!!! It's a phenomenal view of the bridge (show me a view of the bridge that isn't phenomenal!) and that's just the beginning! Lots of history here and a great place to walk (for me, it's after work today!).  Nice weather and gorgeous scenery. The Civil War history is what keeps my boyfriend coming back here as he's a huge history buff. For me, it'd trying to get that perfect shot for my family back east. I'll post some pix from my camera but for now, I'm going to hike around! Definitely come here!!!
author: Sandra P.

description:
Although I've lived in the Bay Area for years, I haven't gotten a picture in front of the Golden Gate Bridge. WTH right? So I took matters into my own hands today and made the trip to Fort Point, a historic spot right by the Golden Gate Bridge. It's free to the public, opens until 5pm and a great spot to take pictures with Golden Gate Bridge in the background. Now I finally have a picture in front of the Golden Gate Bridge!

Tip: It gets really windy up there, so don't wear a skirt and flash people like I maybe did..
author: Christine C.

description: What's not to like? Educational field trip at a beautiful spot under the Golden Gate Bridge. The brick arches are amazing and the whole place has a mini coliseum sort of feel centered around the court yard. I was excited to see the process of Golden Gate Bridge being built and finding out that Alcatraz was a fort before it was ever a prison!
author: Marty J.

description:
We wandered down to Fort Point on Sunday without knowing what we were in store for. This place is great! We had a blast- it was a super windy overcast day but we enjoyed ourselves tremendously. 

Interesting historically and you can't beat the view. Plus, entrance is free. A must for anybody who is in SF.
author: Kristen M.

description:
I went crabbing for the very first time a few weekends ago. It was a sunny hot rare SF kind of day, but at the pier it was so windy. Remember to bring a warm jacket, because it does get cold here.

Brought buckets, hoop nets, fishing line, snacks for the sea creatures (bait), snacks for the humans...made use of all the things we brought.

There were quite a few people crabbing & fishing in this area. We caught many many Dungeness crabs which I call the illegals, but no legal crabs. Remember not to take Dungeness, or else you'll receive a fine, I've heard stories about them, not good. My dad says there are people with binoculars watching...

Nice place to make friends, many people come up to talk to you. Some people look at other people's buckets to see what they caught. Every time someone came over to look at our bucket, they saw NOTHING, how embarrassing...we went home empty handed =[

Parking was hard around 3PM, lots & lots of people. We did find parking closer to the bridge, they had plenty of parking there & the walk wasn't too far.

Good experience, next time we'll know to go earlier...
author: Kylie L.

description: A national historic site! Long lines to the entrance at the bridge?? Veer down to Fort Point next to Crissy Field. On the southern side at the base of the entrance along the bay. Fort Point protected San Francisco harbor from Confederate and foreign attack during and after the U.S. Civil War. Got some great pictures and an awesome view of the bridge! I recommend it! I recommend it! We were here 4th of July weekend. Crazy traffic to cross the bridge so we made a detour down to Fort Point. Totally worth it! Not a lot of traffic, we found parking, learned some history and saw some amazing views of Golden Gate bridge! The cost? $Free.99
author: An L.

description: I love coming out here on nice sunny days.  It's a just a walk up from Crissy Fields, it's free, the volunteers working there are so sweet, and you get an incredible view of the Golden Gate bridge.  The place tends to always be a popular photo spot, so get ready for both tourists and professional photographers looking to get that perfect snap.  But honestly, the place is really beautiful from the top, and kind of hauntingly beautiful in on the different floors.
author: Kristen T.

description: What can I say about Fort point. This place is very historical and intriguing. I got a tour at about noonish and it was very cold so I suggest you bring a jacket. You're able to see a very close up version of the Golden Gate Bridge and also San Francisco. Everything from the bricks to the way everything is designed amazed me. If you ever have a chance to visit, you should. You'll totes take a lot of pictures. It would be a great place to have a photo shoot as well. But please please please bring a jacket..
author: Oscar M.

description: Awesome! Saw some sea lions, surfers and obviously the golden gate bridge
author: Brandi S.

description: Cool place to learn some history. Awesome views. Good place to photograph if you're into that sort of thing.
author: Droger S.

description: Best view of the Golden Gate Bridge! You can also get a history lesson also and check out the weapons used during the Civil War.
author: Danny N.

description:
Fort Point is a great stop along the way to bike the bridge. 

A unique way to see the fort is to book a candlelight tour at night via the National Parks website. It books out fast so you need to plan ahead but it is free and ranger takes you around the fort for you to learn all about the history over 1.5 hours. 

You actually get a candle each to carry around too.
author: Noelle K.

description: I love exploring old forts and this was a good one. First of all, what a location, under the Golden Gate Bridge. Very well preserved. A lot of other civil war era forts are not in such great shape. Well, at least the 2 in Key West are much more deteriorated than this one. Not real large so it doesn't take a lot of time to explore. We did the Presidigo bus to get there from downtown SF. That worked well.
author: Ken J.

description:
Despite living in the city for over six years and biking past this historical site multiple times on my rides over the bridge, I've never actually stopped to check it out. While out walking this past weekend, we stopped by to see how much it cost to get in and discovering it was donation only required, we stopped in to explore!

Sadly it was a cloudy and extremely windy day, so the view, while impressive, would be so much better on a beautiful day. That being said, it was still amazing to see. We hiked up one of the spiral staircases and made it to the rooftop with the cannon mounts and got an amazing view of the bridge and the bay underneath it. 

Since it's right on the very tip of the peninsula, be prepared for some absolutely insanely strong (and chilly!) winds. Explore the fort, read the historical plaques and enjoy the view!
author: Cassandra J.

description: Absolutely beautiful views on a clear day! Love love love this spot. I left my heart in San Francisco and it was left here.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Wow, it took me 30+ years to finally make it out to Fort Point. I can't wait to go back. 

We parked in the lot at Crissy Field and huffed it over to the Fort. I had seen pictures of folks surfing below the bridge and I was happy to see a handful of guys surfing the break.  

The Fort is super cool.  You can walk in for free and explore the old facility. There is a long hallway on the second floor, that looks like it came out of the twilight zone! Check it out. It's creepy. Be careful as you walk up the staircase to the roof, the stairs are narrow and if you use the spiral staircase, there are no handrails. 

The rooftop is the best part because you are right below the Golden Gate Bridge and you'll have a great view of the coast and the city.  

It's about a mile and a half walk from the parking lot to the Fort, well worth your time. Bring a light jacket because it's SF and the weather changes quickly.
author: Mel P.

description:
After a non-productive few hours shopping at Sports Basement, we decided to take a late afternoon walk along Chrissy Field. I've been to the Warming Hut area at the end of Chrissy Field several times, but never really wandered past there. This time, we decided to walk all the way to Fort Point - although at the time we weren't even sure what Fort Point was, exactly. 

It's actually pretty cool, you can wander in the rooms and hallways of the old fort, up and down the spiral staircases, and all along the "ramparts" on top. You're essentially directly under the Golden Gate bridge, so that's an experience in and of itself. 

A few of the rooms in the forts are set up like mini museums, so you can read about shipwrecks, lighthouses, and the military history of SF Bay. Very cool! 

I probably wouldn't go out of my way to check Fort Point out, but if you're wandering around the area, definitely worth a visit.
author: Lindsey B.

description: I got to Fort Point right when it opened and there was plenty of parking available, which is a big deal in San Francisco.  This place was GREAT and the history about the Fort Point along with the views is amazing.  The thing I personally liked the most about this tour was that unlike other ways to see the Golden Gate Bridge, it was FREE.  Another good thing about this tour I didn't have to climb a lot of stairs to view the Golden Gate Bridge, which was good because we took our 6-month baby with us. The view of the bridge from the top of the fort is beautiful and it was hassle free to take pictures.  I was also lucky enough to have a clear day, which just made it even better.  If you're not planning on walking the bridge and have young kids, this is the way to go.
author: Edward G.

description: This hidden gem located under the Golden Gate Bridge is a unique place to stop at while in San Francisco. This fort has an incredible history and the fort itself has an interesting design. We enjoyed looking through their barracks as well as exploring their gift shop. Some of the best views of San Francisco were from the top of the fort and in the end we learned a lot about the shipwrecks at the entrance of the bay. In the end this was an awesome place to stop and I am happy that we spent some time here.
author: Dan R.

description: One of my favorite places hands down in San Francisco. The view of the Golden Gate Bridge here is breathtaking and the fort itself is such a magical place. I always try to come here when I am in the city visiting.
author: Mikhail H.

description:
Awesome site !  Returned several times this year to show visiting relatives this hidden gem right under the Golden Gate Bridge.   We also did the candlelight Saturday night winter tour one more time with a little friend ( 6 year old ) ....  Even she loved it !!
Great spot, great pictures, great history  and a great National Parks Ranger ( Andrew ) who conducted the candlelight tour.....  I hope the powers that be have as much foresight as the Chief Engineer of the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge, Joseph Strauss,  did back in the 1930s , and they invest the time and money that it will take to preserve this magnificent structure for future generations of Americans and the world to see.  Don't miss seeing it and do try to go there when the Fort is open,, due to budget restraints they have limited hours..... hopefully that  will change for the better too ....
author: Patrick C.

description:
Before going on my trip to San Francisco, I researched various places to go see and no where was this placed mentioned.  I am shocked by this since it's such an amazing place.

When you climb to the roof of the fort, you are literally standing just below the Golden Gate Bridge with amazing views of both San Francisco and the Pacific Ocean.

This place is a must see!
author: Karen R.

description:
Fort Point is located at the southern side of the Golden Gate. This fort was completed just before the American Civil War, to defend San Francisco Bay against hostile warships. The fort is now protected as Fort Point National Historic Site and part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.

Plans for the Golden Gate Bridge in the 1930s called for the fort's removal, but Chief Engineer Joseph Strauss redesigned the bridge to save the fort. "While the old fort has no military value now," Strauss said, "it remains nevertheless a fine example of the mason's art.... It should be preserved and restored as a national monument." 

I've walked in directly from the Crissy Field side, but the route I enjoy most is the steep walk down from the Golden Gate Bridge plaza. I love the history and its stark remains, I love the views, I love the unique Bridge angles, I love the Vertigo experience, and I love the cold, windy, and sometimes foggy weather.
author: Eric B.

author: Noe O.

description:
This is probably the very best place to visit in San Francisco, and the Rangers here are all great ( unlike in many other places ): very pleasant and unassuming.
The best!
author: George T.

description:
A must see spot in the city. You can get a great close-up view of the golden gate bridge from fort point and is also a great destination for biking or running.

It's pretty dead during the mornings/evenings so it's pretty casual here but during the afternoon it gets pretty busy as the tourists pour in, especially on those stupid safari buses.

If you are walking/running/biking here, there is technically no sidewalk so make sure you keep an eye out for cars.

Also did I mention it's free? Take a walk through the visitors center and learn about some of the history of the city. Also observe a handful of surfers out in the area--although not sure why you would, the bay is FREEZING!
author: Kameron K.

description:
Cant really critique a tourist spot like this but let me cut straight to the point.

PRO's

- Great running, biking trails around the area

- Amazing place to be in sunny SF weather
- Walk down to the beach, great view of the underside of the bridge

CON's

***CUHHHHRAPPPY PARKING ON WEEKENDS
author: Michael P.

description:
I went on a Sat night 12/11/10 candlelight tour of Fort Point in SF under the Golden Gate Bridge.  You need to make reservations, it's a FREE tour.  I think I called in Nov and had to wait until 12/11/10 to get my spots.

Met the ranger at the Warming Hut.  I think everyone that went on the tour drove, we were the only crazy ones to take the bus from Golden Gate Bridge before the toll plaza and walk down to the Warming Hut.  There's bathrooms near the meeting spot.

Ranger walked us to the Fort & told us historical stuff.  Went into Sally Port where we can borrow & carry a Candlelight Lantern someone told me was a "old fashion hurricane lantern"  It's really neat & make great patterns so bring your camera.

Tour was pretty short from 6:30-8pm.  We went upstairs in mostly darkness & only the lanterns to guide the way.

Worth going in the daytime & nightime.

Candlelight Tours are Nov-Feb, Sat evenings only.  Call To make reservations for this and other programs (415) 556-1693.  Message said it's full - just leave a message & hope for the best. Someone will call u back.

Website:
http://www.nps.gov/fopo/planyourvisit/guidedtours.htm
author: Ann L.

description:
A HAIKU REVIEW

Fort below the bridge
Beautiful. Stunning. Haunting.
Go. Then go again.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Defending our city.

Back in the day this place protected us from unexpected Civil War attacks.

Today you can enjoy reenactments and then stand on top with the Golden Gate Bridge as a backdrop and marvel at the history and beauty of such a heritage rich location.

Can't imagine a world without San Francisco. Thanks Fort Point.
author: Jason B.

description: One of the few spots to enjoy the awesome views of GGB. Make sure to carry a good camera to capture the bridge in the background. One should be lucky to see the bridge with sunlight as most of time bridge is surrounded by fog, i was able to enjoy the view with sunlight and fog both on the same day!
author: Vineet S.

description:
Why in the world the government will not allow leashed dogs in an outdoor courtyard is beyond me! Tried to attend the civil war reenactment but were forced to leave because of our dog meebo. No mention made on the website that dogs were forbidden. 

Lame apologies by a green shirted pensionista.
author: Kelly K.

description:
At 7am you see the runners but have the best views ! I never get board of this place, a must see each visit to SF. I suggest good walking shoes and full camera battery. You get a wonderful view from the top of the building and if your afraid of nights you can still do this...trust me it is so worth the time.

After exploring the halls of history and imaging the moments of long ago...you have to have a coffee and snack from the cafe! Also get a bird treat from the cafe, lots of fun for the little ones.
This Historical landmark is a must see, I would suggest that you give at least 1 hour to really intake all this has to offer!
author: Sandy K.

description:
Why this is the best view in San Francisco:

1. You're right under the Golden Gate Bridge so you get a spectacular view
2. Great spot for taking pictures
3. Well run museum
3. Did I mention, it's FREE.
author: Haily H.

description:
Dates are starting to become innovative and creative as the months add themselves on to my time line of life as a single woman in San Francisco.

Gone are the stereotypical days of being taken to fancy restaurants.  Instead, they have been replaced with the conveniently forgiving $5 date with a cup of coffee.  Add in a trip to the local Fort Point after a nice walk through Chrissy Field and I'll add in kudos points for effort.

Fort Point is an old masonry building standing guard at the mouth of the SF bay.  Once situated within the courtyard, does one truly appreciate the pure craftsmanship and dedication done by the masons back in the day.  One has the option to explore the first floor and read the various posted items on artifacts and daily life at the fort.  

My favorite option, was walking in and out of the areas where the cannons were situated.  Although they have long been removed, their ghostly presence is unmistakable as the rivets and steel paths are still set in stone.  Prodding, below our soled feet.

The top floor is indeed the jewel in this crown.  Massive and clear views of the city and the bay, as well as the underside of the Golden Gate Bridge.  On this specific day, it was overcast, drizzling and the fog had taken over the bridge, but the beauty of true industrial charm was very much clear on this grey day.  And we left, feeling a bit warmer in regards to experiencing a historical site.  Free.  And open until dusk with park police on site to monitor and assist with questions.

More info found here, as well as directions: http://www.nps.gov/fopo/historyculture/index.htm
author: Miika M.

description: This is one of those place that most tourists don't know about. The beauty of this old Army fort is amazing. There are so many levels to explore. I'm sooo glad they didn't tear it down whey they were building the Golden Gate Bridge. It was slated to be razed but they built an arch to save it. I love the fact that they kept the living quarters in tact to see how the soldiers lived. They even post a menu how they ate. So many picture opportunities with your camera. I land up taking dozens. The best ones are in black and white to get that old feel.
author: Douglas A.

description:
I am fascinated by military history and I find it frustrating that there are not more military museums or battlefields in Northern California. Like many poor Californians I had to endure boring state history lessons about the Spanish Missions instead of learning more about the American Revolution or the Civil War(my kind of history!). Luckily Fort Point was one of my earliest introductions to military history & I can remember how wowed I was when I was a little kid.

Despite the confusing route to get to Fort Point and the crowds that can build up, its completely worth a visit. Its also FREE so this makes for a cool cheap date or fun family outing. There's a lot to see so expect to walk quite a bit and climb up some stairs. There are old cannons scattered all over the place as well as original artifacts from the days when Fort Point was in service. 

The tourist and local appeal of Fort Point besides its history is its views of the Bay and the Golden Gate Bridge. You can climb all the way to the top of the fort and see one hell of a view, but it is very windy so make sure you're dressed appropriately. The gift store is pretty nice for its size, with something for everyone. Overall its not a bad way to spend a hour or two in the city.
author: Paul E.

description:
Meander your way through Chrissy Fields and through Presidio to find this hidden local gem. Located right under the Golden Gate Bridge, this fort is free and offers amazing views and picture opportunities of both the Bridge and the City.

The inside skeletal of the Fort is free for viewing. You can often find surfers taking advantage of the Pacific waves underneath the bridge. Joggers come through to high-five Hopper's Hands. It's a great place to take pictures and get an unique view of the Bridge.

It's right by the water so remind yourself and your fellow out-of-towners to bring a windbreaker or jacket! It can get pretty freezing down there, even in the middle of summer!
author: Vivian A.

description:
Great viewpoint and fun hang out spot!

 It's completely FREE and open to the public, so be sure to stop by here for great pictures and a visit to the Fort! There's a lot of historical information around the Fort, and it's fun to visit all the rooms. The stairs to the top are amazingly windy and it's fun to take pictures on the very top floor. 

My favorite picture spot is in the parking lot right by the fort where the entire Golden Gate Bridge stands as the back drop of all your photos. It's amazing on sunny, windy, AND rainy days. (as it was windy and extremely windy when i went and I still had an amazing time) This place is a must when visiting SF!
author: Donna V.

description: Cool free tourist attraction and spot for a better picture location of the bridge.
author: Jason F.

description: I have come here many times over the years and as usual the fort is closed to visitors because I love to visit it at night. Normally I can just sit there and listen to the waves crash upon the beach and into the sea wall. This time however I was in the City to do night photography and chose this place because of the great views of the bay. Unfortunately in the hour I was there a steady stream of headlights bathed my cameras in light... =/ ... I got fed up and left.
author: Christy P.

description:
I'm not sure why I've never reviewed this place until now.
In my opinion, Fort Point has the best view of the GG bridge; the underside of the bridge is gorgeous, you can see it span all the way to Marin, the photo opps are unbeatable and I always take my out-of-town friends there.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: awesome historical landmark/museum. I remember going here on school field trips. It gives you a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the roof. I walked into one room and there was a lady dressed in old clothes explaining to us what the things on the tables were. Best of all it's free to visit!
author: Tri V.

description:
Open 7 days a week for Summer 2012! This Fort has been here for a L-O-N-G time, in fact, all the way back to Spanish settlers and gives some of the best views of the Golden Gate Bridge. There have been all sorts of upgrades and additions to the area and there is a lot of really cool history and exhibits inside, not to mention a lighthouse as well.

Last, there's an art exhibit called International Orange that is showing until October. All of the stuff there ties directly in to the history of the bridge or the Fort OR it enhances your visit. There's camera obscura, which projects in live images of the bay using a darkened room, a canvas, and a hole that lets in light. There's neat civil war era dresses made out of crepe paper featuring some of the hi-lights of local SF parks and history, there's a GIANT screen with video taken from around the fort, a room featuring live sounds of the Bay and the Bridge...yea, it's pretty awesome and well worth checking out. Best part: It's F-R-E-E to visit (there is a donation box though!)
author: Lily K.

description: Such a great spot to take a photo of the bridge! Even on a cloudy day :) Make sure you walk around after you get dropped off for a better photo spot! There is also a gift shop and restaurant near by :) Beautiful tourist spot!
author: Maricris M.

description:
Interesting how a city like San Francisco is known for peace-loving hippie liberals but probably has more military forts than any city in the world with Fort Point, Fort Scott, Fort Mason, Fort Miley, and Fort Funston. And of course, the Presidio consumes a sizable amount of SF real estate. I guess this shouldn't surprise me since the playground for the tie-dye generation was on Haight (sounds like hate) Street.

Regardless, Fort Point is perhaps the BEST TOURIST ATTRACTION IN THE BAY AREA and it probably doesn't even make the top 10 in tourist attendance even though there is free parking and free admission. I've only seen one other old fort that can compare - Fort Pulaski in Georgia. Although Pulaski was located on an island facing the Atlantic with cannonball damage and an alligator moat with drawbridge, Pulaski's incredible views don't include spectacular underneath angles of the Golden Gate Bridge.

To top it all off, there were art exhibits throughout the Fort as part of the 75th anniversary celebration of the Golden Gate Bridge. It made for a very complete 1 hour and 15 minute outing.

I have one more point (pun intended) to make about the Golden Gate Bridge. San Franciscan's have a weird idea of what looks golden. The bridge is painted orange-red like they are Texas Longhorn fans. The waterway is constantly dreary and foggy - not sunlit with the golden Californian sun.
author: Brian U.

description:
If you come to SF and don't visit Fort Point, you're really missing out. Incredibly well-run museum. Beautiful location. Awesome exhibits, as well as interactive demonstrations of canon-loading. The place really gives you a feel for the bay's early history, where invasion was a big thought on people's minds.       

I didn't give it 5 stars, because like many other National Park Service Parks these days, this place has started getting into the trendy "Hey, let's do an art exhibit here!" craze. This is stupidity. They had some really stupid artist exhibits setup in various barracks rooms on the south side of the fort. It's TOTALLY UNRELATED TO THE HISTORIC FABRIC OF THE FORT, AND ITS CONTEXTUAL HISTORY. IT DOES NOT BELONG THERE!!!!! 

Historical monuments, parks and museums are just that, they're not goddamned art galleries.
author: Jay A.

description:
First stop, Day 2 in San Francisco :) 

This spot is seriously the best place to view the Golden Gate Bridge. The best. 

I loved that I could see how the bridge was structured from way up close and that I could take as many photos as I wanted with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background without having to fight tourists for the nice photos.

Warning: it's a bit confusing to get there. 

Here's a tip on how-to-get-here if you want to avoid accidentally crossing the bridge and having to pay a toll to get back: 

1.Head towards the Bridge from San Fran side. 
2.Turn RIGHT into a pathway, JUST BEFORE the bridge. That path should take you to Fort Point (while following the road signs as well) 

I say it's even better than Vista Point because it's less crowded. 

Positives: 
(+) plenty of parking spots right by the ocean. 
(+) you can get a bunch of really nice photos taken right of the Golden Gate Bridge
(+) the fort itself is kind of cool to look at as well :)
(+) avoid $6.00 toll fee. YES!
author: Julie Y.

description:
I love coming to this historic places like this whenever we vacation in SF.  Being from LA we don't have as many old historic places like SF and in such a smaller area.  SF being alot older they have alot more old military sites which I love to visit and this area has LOADs.  Be sure to also check out the Presideo, Coastal Batteries, National Cemetery.

This is a great place to get lower shots of the Golden Gate.  Its lit up very nicely in the morning if it clear or you can get a nice silhouette shot at sunset at the end of the day but morning to Noon time is better light from that side.

Also very popular and a good place to go running, biking, walking, picnicking, etc.
author: Damon D.

description:
This place is so much fun! I have a friend in town and so we went walking through the Marina and headed up to Ft. Point. We had a half hour, but it was plenty of time. If you are into the military at all there is some good history, but me, I went for the views. 

You literally can go to the roof and see the entire city as well as across the bay, the whole bridge, Alcatraz, and more. Ladies: do not attempt to do your hair before you go here, the wind is out of control and will blow your hair in 30 directions! Definitely bring a sweater and a camera too!
author: M M.

description:
It's funny how many places you miss when you live in a city. Yup, this was one of them. I could've come here when I was kid, I don't know, I don't remember- we used to go crabbing years ago but I couldn't tell you where. We went here on our most recent trip to the Bay Area (april/may 2010). Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's. According to the website, open Fri- Sun 1-am to 5 pm. Historical site during the Civil War; the Presidio was once an active military base.

Super windy and coldy even on a sunny day, bring a sweater or jacket. There were quite a bit of people fishing. There are public restrooms (open front door) but no mirror, so check your face in your compact. Fun place to walk around and take pictures with the beautiful Golden Gate Bridge in the background- it's iconic. Lots of people walking, and biking (tourists- these bikes had maps affixed to the handle bars- saw them all over the city). Lots of dogs, too. Family-friendly.

I guess one could have a picnic here if you didn't mind the cold wind. And it would probably help if the food was cold too.

There was a ton of construction in the area so some roads were closed off. Parking was not a problem. There were many others in the area.
author: Margret C.

description:
The sights alone are worth the trip. Staring out at the never ending horizon right underneath the bridge is too romantic. Lookout for the heavy gusts of winds if you're a hat wearer. If you bring your kids keep a close eye on them because the steep stairs have no railing. On the rooftop you can also easily climb the wall and die. Some people were doing this, they had to be gigantic idiots.

Throughout the three or four floors of Fort Point there are some rooms showcasing photos, artifacts, and models illustrating its historical past. When I went there was also an exhibition of artwork reflecting on the Golden Gate bridge, yet I hardly found any pieces. If you want to truly experience the Golden Gate Bridge you should come here. And it's free so there's nothing to complain about.
author: Michael H.

description: Come here to get a great upclose view of the bridge.  This location is better than the area where they have the souvenir store plus you get to check out the fort.   Less people here too.
author: Kazuo O.

description:
AMAZING, historic, wonderful.  This is a hidden jewel of San Francisco - great for kids, great for history buffs, great just for the views of the San Francisco bay.  If you are any of the above, be sure to add this to your next trip to San Francisco.

Dress WARMLY - it is almost always VERY cold, with lots of WIND.  The parking by the way is pretty good - we can almost always find a spot.
author: Jason M.

description: I'm so glad we took the time to stop off here and visit Fort Point while visiting the Golden Gate Bridge. I never realized this was once a U.S.Army installation long ago. There are cannons on display inside the fort and there is a small gift shop that sells some neat stuff. Go up to the upper level and you have a beautiful view of the bridge and the bay!!! Makes for some great scenery for picture taking. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there. Go visit there when in San Francisco and also, help support our National Park Service.
author: Dave F.

description: This place is a real gem. Did anyone know they almost tore it down to construct the Golden Gate bridge? Thankfully, they adjusted the the plans to go around the Fort (South-end of the bridge is different).  Amazing history and views. We especially appreciated seeing all the GG paint splatters all over the place. Funny. A must-see place when coming to San Francisco!
author: Elisa D.

description:
I've been debating long and hard whether to just write any one of the reviews for my 3000th or wait until something worthy came along -- whether to write a 1 star or a 5 star -- and ultimately, the 5 star won. So here I go with my 3000th review dedicated to a beautiful spot in a city that I have yet to fall out of love with.............

We had time to kill before embarking on to dinner and the sun was shining, the breezes were blowing and it was a clear day, so clear you could see Coit Tower, Alcatraz and of course, the Golden Gate Bridge.

I'd been to various parts of the bay where a glimpse of the GG Bridge stands majestically whether it was a day such as this, or one which was laden with fog. Today, the clear blue skies were the perfect backdrop for the bridge -- not a cloud in sight.

It was the first time I'd visited Fort Point -- didn't even know it was there -- and from that angle, the GG looked even grander than before. It's not called Fort Point for nothing because there really is a fort -- well, one left over from the Civil War, or whatever the remnants of it remains. Windy staircases intrigued all the little children there when they reached each level and found eerie corridors and cavernous corners in which to run around in. 

When you get to the top, there is a 'lighthouse' looking thing and several signs reminding you to stay off the walls. The winds are brutal up here! The sunshine does nothing to stave off the freezing cold of the gusts pounding into you, but somehow, you relent because the sight is quite magnificent.

I was mesmerized again by how beautiful San Francisco is, and how sad that I no longer live in this gorgeous city by the bay!!
author: Anita L.

description: The absolute best view of the Golden Gate Bridge! This is a hidden gem that you must go to if you're visiting the bay area! This Fort is located below the bridge along the ocean, perfect up-close view of the bridge! I came here on a gloomy/hazy day, and was still blown away by the beautiful view. I can imagine how amazing it would be on a clear sunny day.
author: Kelsie K.

description:
An awesome spot to take someone if they've never been to SF before. Full of history on every level. It's a nice spot to wonder around and be immersed in past times. If you take the stairs all the way to the top, you can get a really close look of the Golden Gate Bridge. Awesome spot to sit down and take pictures. I was considering coming here to take engagement photos. It's so beautiful (if you like that rusty look).

If you take Mason St. all the way towards Golden Gate Bridge from the Marina, you'll find free parking at the very end. From there, it's like a 5 min walk. I don't know where to go to park closer. It may require a parking fee that way.

It can get a bit cold there, so remember to bring a jacket.
author: Rosie W.

description:
As we were driving towards this place on a nice Saturday afternoon, my kids asked the wifey how old was I.

Conversation went like this:

10 year old: Mom, how old is Dada?
Wifey: Why?

10 year old: He looks old.
13 year old: He's thirty ____ years old.

Wifey: Yeah, he's getting old.
10 year old: If he's that old, he needs to take a "Prostitute Test."
.
.
.
.
.
The rest of the afternoon went great and no it did not include any prostitutes. Took the dogs running in Crissy Field with a wonderful backdrop of the bridge and sailboats in the bay. Fort Point has a lot of history displayed right before your eyes, and it's truly an amazing and beautiful place.

The only kind of test I want to take is an "Eye Test" and yes..maybe even a visit to the doctor to make sure I get to enjoy what the city has to offer us.
author: John G.

description: Why go to Alcatraz when you can come to Fort Point for FREE!!!!! you get the beautiful view of the bay, and an even more amazing view of the Bridge. I loved running around where ever i wanted to wonder. I saw all levels, when we arrived it was very foggy and overcast, it was cold and windy but it was still my favorite part of my trip. Til next time :D
author: lesly l.

description: Free! This is a great place to stop or end a bike ride along Crissy Field. Most people don't know this little historical gem exists. Did I mention it is free?!!!
author: Danny B.

description: I went here for part of my engagement photo shoot a few years ago. Lots of nooks and crannies to take neat pictures under the bridge and of the city, but not much else. There's unfortunately graffitti on the walls and a lot of the area is blocked off. It's an interesting place, specifically because of its age, but nothing to go out of your way to come see, necessarily.
author: Rachel S.

description: We came here a third time.. still too much fog to see the Golden Gate Bridge, but we caught a glimpse of it.  I can only imagine what the view would look like without any fog.. probably AMAZING!
author: Mindy T.

description:
Surfers.
Seals.
Dolphins.
Fog.
History.
What else could one ask for?
It's a popular place for people walking, biking and on tour buses.
Definitely crowded on weekends, but there are unparalleled views of the Bay and the Bridge from this angle.
author: Ken B.

description: Fort Point is forgotten by most locals and even major tourist companies, but if you're a history buff, it's an experience you won't forget. The cannons and quarters fascinated me, as did the view of the Golden Gate Bridge. The staff are some of the most courteous I've seen for any business I've yelped, and the gift shop, while somewhat expensive, is worth it, considering that the visit itself is free.
author: Paul K.

description: A great place to see Golden Gate Bridge! Parking is always an issue in San Francisco, but we found a free parking place!  We drove through the small tunnel, and it was located on the right after bus stop.  There are not many choice of souvenir so we didn't buy anything.  Pricy too!!!
author: Chelsea C.

description: Pretty beautiful. Terribly cold! Saw dolphins!
author: Keila M.

description:
Simply awesome! 

Fort Point is a fantastic tourist spot if you're in the city. Not just for a lesson on California history but for amazing photo ops. Standing at the base of the Golden Gate bridge you'll get some amazing views here. 

It had been almost 20 years since my first visit and I liked it more as an adult than I did when I was just 8.
author: Katy H.

description: Went here with my family. We had a fabulous time exploring and learning the history of the Fort. Admission is free, but you can make a donation when you leave. It was overcast and very windy when we were there. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes and take a jacket just in case. You will be walking up three flights of stairs to the very top of the Fort. The day we were there it was scary windy for me. Plus I didn't have a jacket and I was freezing up there at the top of the Fort. But I must say you get the best views of the Golden Gate here , you are literally underneath it and you hear the many cars speeding by. At the top you also have excellent views of the city as well. I would highly recommend this as a must see! They have a gift shop as well, I think it was on the first floor so no stairs to get to it. We parked for free in the lot by the Fort. Also I think Yelp has their hours of operation wrong as the sign I saw said: Fort Point is open Friday through Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. So I would check their website just to be sure they're open for your visit.  Have fun! :)
author: Christine C.

description: Best spot to get up close and personal with the Golden Gate Bridge.  Just spectacular.  Isn't it amazing how many possible views there are of the Bay and Golden Gate Bridge, and they're just all.. amazing?  This one in particular because this is literally as close as you can get.  Fort Point is directly under the GG Bridge, and you can see the waves come so close, it's maybe 1-2 feet from the ledge.  One of the best views, without all the hassle.
author: Mel G.

description: The five star rating says it all... if you're visiting San Francisco and want a unique view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the surrounding area this is one of the places you must visit. Access is easy, but it can be crowded on nice days/weekends.  Make sure you go to the 'top' of the fort for the $$$ views!
author: Mike J.

description: Unfortunately wasn't able to stroll through the museum since it was closed but still had a great time taking in the view. From this point you are at the bottom of the Golden Gate. There's free parking along the water. It's actually quite a refreshing view of the water and bridge. Still great for pictures or just to take in the view.
author: Stephie D.

description:
Everything happens for a reason.

That's what I like to think.

Getting lost this weekend, on the way to the Palace of Fine Arts, in the rain, we had to walk past Fort Point.

Even admidst our arguing over who had messed up the walking directions, we had to...

STOP

GASP

and MARVEL 

As the rain started to soak through our thin layers, we stopped walking. 

Our "well if you had only...." "I told you!..." s stopped as well. And as our umbrella tugged in the wind, we stood captivated by one of the best panoramic views of the San Francisco skyline. 

I don't know if I will even be able to leave San Francisco.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Love this spot. I've been coming here since I was a little kid with my family. Even if you live in the bay area and it's normal to pass by the bridge, this place still is beautiful as ever. 

I always get lucky because whenever I come I usually see lots of surfers in the water. Just the other day there were 14 surfers catching waves. Awesome.

I never tried driving towards the Golden Gate bridge to get here because it can get confusing and I don't want to pay bridge toll if I miss my exit so i always take the local streets towards Chrissy Fields all the way to the end.

The historical building closes a little early around 5 I believe. It's free and interesting!
author: Annissa H.

description:
International orange exhibition.
A great photography site.
Get a best view from UNDER the bridge--but is less favorable than Marina headland.
Very Windy-cautious
author: Bing G.

description: Another great place to take tourists and people who love history.  It gets really chilly, in here and I swear every time I come here it's raining or on the verge of raining.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
Go to the top floor & make out there, too.  :)

Interesting history and ya, it's kinda romantic, despite the fact you're on an old fort.  Let's face it, maybe that's the charm: love and war are synonymous at times we all know this.  

Although we went on a holiday where Chrissy Field seemed packed, not many ventured as far down as the fort, and it's not usually packed with tourists like the bridge above.
author: Athena S.

description: This is probably my favorite "tourist" place in SF. The architecture is amazing and the view of the bridge is perfect. The whole time I kept thinking what a perfect spot it would be to play hide and seek with a big group of people because of all the fun stair cases, rooms, and unexpected corners.
author: Brittany H.

description: Excellent views, lots of fresh air.
author: April M.

description: Fort Point is definitely a hidden gem in San Francisco. I was doing a search online for cool places to see the GG Bridge from and Fort Point was one of them. I'm glad I decided to go. I went on a Sunday (it's only open Fri.-Sun.) around 1pm and had no trouble finding it or locating a place to park. There were no lines to get in, no crowds to deal with while inside; I felt like I had the place all to myself even though there was other people there. This is a great spot to get an up close view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Erin R.

description: I walked from Pier 39 to here.... and it was SO worth it! the views are fantastic, and it is free to get in. well worth a visit!
author: K. D.

description: The chocolate I bought from the nearby coffee shop had ants in them... but the place was nice, and it was entertaining watching the fishers fish at the dock area. The view is amazing.  Such a beautiful place.
author: Maly V.

description:
BEAUTIFUL! 
My boyfriend and I decided to take the bus to Fort Point (the 29 and/or the 28 takes you) then walked the entire area. We ended up walking all the way back to the Marina from Fort Point. It was lovely! Can't wait to go back!!!
author: Christina K.

description:
I love riding my bike out here on a sunny weekday with a book and lunch packed up. Gorgeous green carpeting covers the few mounds of dirt that lay just a few steps away from the historical buildings of the area.

There is parking if you need it, otherwise, just walk, run, ride a bike, skate over there and park your ass on the grass and enjoy the beautiful view of the bridge and frolicking canines.
author: Anne Marie S.

description:
Wow.  Eleven years in San Francisco and working way too much.   Finally my spouse and I played tourist the other day and discovered this great historic site.  

It's free!  It provides a powerful peek into the history of our City and the surrounding area.   Volunteers and Rangers, too, are a joy to chat with and full of information.

Don't miss this!
author: Schuyler R.

description:
I found the Fort while getting lost on the way to the Golden Gate Bridge. I came in via the Crissy Field exit and parked at the bottom of the bridge and just walked over to the fort. I never knew it existed, but was awed by it! 

There were surfers by the rocks, fellow tourists swarming the bridge above us, and countless bikers and joggers taking in the bayside views from Crissy Field. Watch out for them as you drive, the roads are very narrow! 

Fort Point is an old pre-Civil War era fortress. It has real cannons and cannonballs lined up against the walls. You can climb up these giant round staircases to the very top. Every floor has an exhibit. One section was devoted to women in the Civil War, others to the soldiers, officers and even the kitchen code of the American Army. Going up to the rooftop gives AMAZING views of the city and the bridge. There are lots of dark corners and narrow alleyways, that make it all the more real. 

If you decide to stop by it's drafty so bring a jacket, give a dollar or two in donations (entrance is free) and tip your hat to the park rangers. It's an awesome place, I would definitely go again!
author: Sharan S.

description:
Gas $14.44, Hot Dog at the Warming Hut $5.50...The view at Fort Point = PRICELESS!!!!  :o)

Visiting the Fort was an experience I will never forget. We first we to Crissy Field *(also highly reccommended)* then went to the Warming Hut (right near the Fort) for a hot dog. Parking is limited at the Fort but worth the hassle. Its nothing fancy but if you can appreciate the awesome view from the top its definetly breathtaking!
author: Amber H.

description:
A hidden gem in the Presidio!

We were at Crissy Fields and ended up wandering around Fort Point after a quick walk towards the bridge. 

Fort Point is the last of its kind (one of 5 forts) that was built to make sure no enemies come into the SF Bay. It has 7 foot thick walls and tiny openings for canons. And a fantastic view of the bridge, the bay, and of Alcatraz. 

We caught a tour (that ended up just being the two of us) but we learned a lot and saw so many things like the gunpowder room, the canon replicas, the canon balls (9inches and 15 inches), and the various rooms before ending up on top with a fantastic view.  

You definitely receive a unique view of the Golden Gate Bridge due to the fact that the architect who designed it, made some modifications to save Fort Point due to it's masonry (the bricks were hand cut to fit all the arches). 

Then we stayed for the canon loading demonstration. So much fun! The BF had a blast and we were glad we stopped by. 

Just bring a hairtie and a warm jacket. The winds here are pretty gusty!
author: Julia W.

description: I remember visiting this place ever since I was a little kid. As I got older I appreciated this place for its historical significance as a World War II defense facility. Now I enjoy pulling my car into the parking lot just as much for the open bay view and that of the Golden Gate Bridge right above it.
author: H K.

description:
Definitely one of the most overlooked landmarks in San Francisco.  People come to see downtown, the bridges, the piers, Alcatraz, and all that good stuff, but this place is just as sharp of an attraction.  It's located right below the Golden Gate Bridge, so when you go on the roof and look directly up...hello!

There were debates of tearing the fort down during the planning of the Golden Gate, but thankfully they let it stand.  Couldn't get tickets for Alcatraz?  Downtown packed?  Not a problem.  Check out Fort Point.  It's free!...at least back in the day it was.  Not too sure now.  Even if they charge a fee it won't be much.  It's eerie walking through the old barracks and checking out the cannons and all that good stuff.  And seriously, go on the roof.  You won't regret it.

Definitely check out Fort Point if you're passing by SF.
author: Greg B.

description: cold! but i love walking around this place, lots of history around here, the sea crashing the side of the cliff. There are wonderful echoes in the fort and its exactly the same as it was in the past. There are three floors but the top is the best, it has a wonderful view. theres a little store i think on the 2nd floor. Like i said before its cold but since there are stairs, it should keep things cool. But my favorite stairs in the medieval stairway inside the building. Lots of cannons, uniforms and quarters have been preserved.
author: Debby D.

description: I love bringing my out of town guests here.  If you climb to the rooftop, you can get some cool views of the bridge, the ocean/ bay, cute surfers and the city skyline.  It's kinda cold though, so bring a jacket!
author: Y B.

description: Yes this is one of my favorite places. GREAT architecture. Love it. I want to film a movie in there. It's under the Golden Gate Bridge so there's the novelty and view of that. It's great. Plus the historical factor of it just makes it that much more mysteriously magical
author: Angela L.

description:
AMAZING!

I came here for my first time even though I've been living here for my life (20 years) This place is banging nice, swear! I recommend taking your date, family, friends, or even yourself here on a sunny day. You'll get the nice view right underneath the famous golden gate bridge and also the historic building is amazingly clean and beautiful! 

Free admission (and I really hope that doesn't change!!) Amazing view (Be sure to bring your cameras!!) I just love it here. No disappointment!
author: Valerie N.

description: Although the view from here is splendid, the fort itself is only open Friday through Sunday, even during the holiday season, which was disappointing.  I took the boy down here to take pictures, but since it was a Thursday, no tour of the Fort for us.  Maybe next time.
author: Sara C.

description:
Nothing to go out of your way for but it's interesting place to see for an hour.
Not that great a spot for photography of people and it's just an empty building with alot of sealed off areas but it's something to do if you're spending some time by the Golden Gate bridge anyway.

Parking is random, usually hard to come by but the view is nice if you go.
author: Jon P.

description: I've been to Fort Point many times.  When I was a young one, and now as a more seasoned individual.  Today's trip was to see the U.S.S. Iowa sail underneath the Golden Gate bridge.  The place was roaring like a wind tunnel, but the views made up for it.  What a fantastic day.  The fort itself is still in great condition, and the best part is that it's free.  What more can you want?
author: Old School G.

description:
While driving through the Presidio we made our way down to Fort Point and I think it has got to be one of the most beautiful places to enjoy the views of all that SF has to offer. We were down to the side of the Golden Gate bridge, across from Alcatraz and the City skyline. It's definitely a serene spot.

It's also a great spot to take a jog, go on a bike ride or just sit around and watch the surfers at the base of the Golden Gate Bridge surfing along the rocks. That was intriguing to me since I'm from LA and not used to seeing surfers at the base of humongous bridges surfing near rocks and stuff!
author: Lori K.

description: Great place to kill some time while visiting San Francisco. Great view of the bay and a nice close up view of the Golden Gate Bridge which is right over the fort. There is also a cool old lighthouse on top of the fort. Some nice artifacts like canons can also be found around the fort.
author: Paul T.

description:
Fort Point is another place one of those natural beauty places that I love in San Francisco.  I come here, no matter what the weather (even if it's raining).  

This is one of my favorite places to take pictures of the fort, the golden gate bridge and marin county.  On the weekends, it's insanely crowded with tourists and almost unbearable to naviagate through the narrow street with a car, as there are tons of tour buses that hog the parking here.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Interesting part of California history, free if you choose not to donate, and has fairly ample parking.  And the views, who doesn't love seeing the bottom of the Golden Gate, Alcatraz, the city skyline?  The fort itself can be explored on your own or on a ranger tour.  The rangers are excited to be there, one was so happy to point out a red tail hawk to us today.  Make sure you bring a sweater or jacket, it's cold and damp, and very windy on the top floor.  Imagine living there before electricity and heaters; the view wouldn't make up for the discomfort!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Make a reservation if you want to go crabbing. It starts with a demo at 10am and you get to crab for two hours.I was totally expecting to have crab for dinner and basically came home empty handed. It was fun just hanging around with friends, but if you're only catching dungeness crabs...which are crabs that we can't take home...it's a little sad. 

remember to bring buckets, a warm coat and some squid bait. and you've got yourself a party!
author: Heidi L.

description:
How in the hell have I lived in SF for almost a year, and I am only just NOW finding out about Fort Point?!! My fiance went here today to have our engagement photos done, and it was beyond amazing.

Firstly- free parking.. and lots of it. We went around noon on a saturday and had NO troubles finding a spot. 

Secondly- free admission (you can/should leave a little donation though).

Third- AMAZING incredible views of the Golden Gate Bridge and downtown. Seriously, incredible. You feel like you are about to make love to the bridge. It's ridiculous.

Fourth- The building itself is completely open to the public, and full of countless nooks and crannies for you to explore and discover.. and, all things considered, it's relatively quiet. We had MUCH of the place to ourselves.. which made for amazing photos!

To me, it absolutely rivaled Alcatraz. A must see if you are new to San Francisco, or just looking for something new to discover. We will absolutely be going back!!
author: Tamara B.

description: Amazing brickwork, crashing waves, killer views, dark corners to lurk into and make out.   It doesn't get any better than this.
author: Meg W.

description: I don't know what else to say except the view here is understatedly indescribable and breathtaking at the very least and grandeur and amazing as well. The ocean here is relatively calm and you get a great view of the Golden Gate bridge as well as a cool little detour at the museum that you can view some history at further down towards the underside of the bridge. This place is difficult to find but well worthy the drive and Presidio in general is pleasant and very different place from the rest of San Francisco. Definitely a must visit when you come to SF!
author: Lorrie M.

description: Amazing views. Very cool landmark. Lots of history. What more could you want? It's a bit cold so bring a jacket but be prepared to wander around for a while. A must see destination.
author: Matt R.

description:
Beautiful spot to take photos of the picturesque Golden Gate bridge from down under. You see from fishermen's, joggers, tourist to surfers here. 

A friend once told me, he went to surf there and saw a dead body swept against the rocks. =x.
author: Tam T.

description: What can I say, but this is the best place to get a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Bring a jacket and marvel in the glory of the bridge!  Highly recommended!!
author: H Q.

description:
I've walked on the Golden Gate Bridge a few times and wondering what people were doing on top of the building below. Finally I figured it out. There's a fort! 

Only open Thurs-Mon during limited hours, it's a gem to explore. Off-the-well-beaten track. Still a lot of tourists. Saw a tourist group get off one of a bus (well not really a bus, but one of those tour vehicles) called the "Urban Safari." It had zebra stripes and plants sprouting out of it. 

Bring a jacket, it gets windy on top of the fort! There's not too much to see, but it's a fun place to explore!
author: Eric C.

description:
My dad was the first to bring me here.  I was just a youngling.  He taught me how to fish and crab.  I had my own matching mickey mouse fishing rod and tackle box. keke he always held onto my hood when i walked around the dock, afraid i might fall over.  They havent created the child-leash yet back then.  There are no walls or any kind of fence so you can easily fall over into the ocean.

Recently I came back here for my birthday, idk, just to feel young again i suppose, but I had to free whatever I caught because killing things on my birthday isnt nice.  Too bad when you throw fish back, the seagulls get to it before it gets a chance to swim away.  :[

since then Ive come back often!!  Ive seen 3 people catch baby leopard sharks. I wouldve freaked.  and kept it as a pet.

I caught 10 fish today with 1 shrimp yay! :] victory never tasted so good.

11/10 times its windy as HECK here, so PLEASE wear a jacket, no joke.

On a sunny day you can see the WHOLE golden gate bridge as you fish.  Sometimes i forget that its there.  But when i see tourists come from far far away, wearing short shorts on the coldest/foggiest day, to come see our bridge, it makes me proud to be an sfransican.
author: kim w.

description:
Another SF landmark for a quick postcard snapshot.   It's not really exciting inside the fort though.

My video of it:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7A_lYNIsVOU
author: Jeff H.

description:
One of the best places to go in the city for a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the bay. 

It's just a short walk past the warming hut at Crissy Field, or you can drive up to it, there's a small parking lot right out in front of the fort. The fort itself seems pretty well preserved. Go up to the top floor and you'r rewarded with a panoramic view of both the Pacific Ocean on one side and the San Francisco Bay on the other. The fort also doubles as a mini museum, although the displays are not exceptionally interesting. The various cannons that they have are pretty cool, but other than that, there are only a couple of rooms where you can look at a recreation of the soldiers' quarters and infirmary. There are also some really random displays on totally non-related subjects like women's suffrage. One of the more fascinating exhibits is the history of how the Golden Gate Bridge was constructed. It details the original plans, the architects involved, pictures of the bridge as it was being built, and now it features a video about the bridge. I learned that one of the primary financiers of building the bridge was Amadeo Giannini, the founder of Bank of America. 

Fort Point is a great place to take visitors.
author: Saunders C.

description:
Along with Chrissy Field, the pier, and the Golden Gate bridge, this is a pretty awesome place. Just like everyone has said, the views are amazing. 

I've been here crabbing a few times at night and once during a Saturday afternoon. Needless to say, the whole area was packed with all sorts of people on Saturday. We were greeted by runners, tourists, photographers, kids, rangers, and everyone in between. Two crabbers, one kid and one adult, got pinched by their catches the last time I was there. They were ok so it was pretty funny.

For those late night crabbing sessions, don't forget to dress warm and bring a flashlight. The pier has no lights at all. 

Don't forget that you can only take rock crabs from here and they have to be min. 4 inches. Size does matter.

P.S. If you see someone yanking really hard on their crab net trying to pull it up, it usually means the net is stuck and not that they have "big catch".
author: JT T.

description: I run here multiple times a week at different times of the day and it never gets old. It's quite refreshing and one of the best close up views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Even when the weather isn't great it's amazing to watch the fog roll through or watch the waves crash upon the rocks. Fort Point constantly reminds me that I live in one of the most beautiful cities in the world.
author: Lauren B.

description: Great place to bike.  Fat people can't run.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I caught my first fish ever at Fort Point.  A rock cod fish approx. 5 lbs.  I was only 3 years old.  Still got the pic to prove it!  All those precious moments spent at Fort Point on weekends fishing and hiking with my brothers and Grandpa.  
Every time I go to Fort Point, I remember those happy times.  Happy times that have long past, but forever in memory.
The fog horn, the salty air, the landmarks - all remains the same and constant reminders of childhood joyful moments - in pictures and in memory. 
Pictures of you.  Pictures of me. 
Hung up on your wall for the world to see. 
Pictures of you.  Pictures of me. 
Remind us all of what we used to be.
author: Marzan W.

description:
Surf Frisco? Sure, just as long as you say "San Francisco" and not "Frisco". 

You could get your ass kicked for doing that around here. Forget being an OT (out-of-towner) surfing their local spot, don't you EVER say "Frisco!" 

When the Federal armies built this fort (http://www.nps.gov/arc...) to protect the City from marauding Confederate warships, they didn't know that they'd be creating a very unique ocean wonder, a respectable surfing spot directly beneath the Golden Gate Bridge. While the fort never had to repel any attacks (a futile feudal fort, hehe, I crack myself up), the base is battered every day by relentless tides and waves that surfers cherish. Now administered by the National Park Service, it's open to the public and the buildings are boring, yet the location is...magnificent! But, enough of the war stuff, my review concerns what I think of whenever Fort Point is mentioned and it's not brick and mortar walls or gun emplacements. If you're more interested in the killing stuff, move on to another review...this is about the thrilling stuff...

A small parking area just in front of the break offers an extremely easy entry into the churning cold pacific and, as always, timing the swells critical unless you want to be peeling yourself off the rocks and looking for the broken pieces of your board. But compared to paddling out in overhead North Ocean Beach, it's easy.

Besides North Beach and a couple other lesser known surf spots, my brother and I would get wet here whenever we'd meet up in the City for our birthdays (we're twins). Describing the feeling of being with a favorite family member, sitting on a board between sets right under the GGB is impossible to describe. There's a surfer saying "Only a surfer knows the feeling" that, while sounding somewhat trite and disingenuous, is 100% spot-on. As you sit idly waiting for a wave, the swells rise and fall beneath you, the ocean cold and dark and on a foggy morning, you can feel completely isolated right here in the City. Paddling back out after a ride, you are overwhelmed by the massive concrete and steel legs of the bridge where fog often hides the upper structures from view. Sometimes the fog is so thick, you can't even see the surfer right next to you. Disembodied voices are heard "Hey, do you know where we are?" "No way, but I think I hear rocks." comes a reply. "Hey, have you seen my brother?"Sure sis,I'm right here!"  I'd been sitting right next to my brother! Time for a crab sammie down on the wharf. One more wave first though. This is Fort Point.

Are you interested in a morbid anecdote? Sure you are. I know what you want.

Fog can play major tricks on the mind, especially when you're alone. We'd be in the dark wild ocean where sharks live and feed. Big sharks...think Jaws (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZvCI-gNK_y4). Now and then, when visibility was near zero and it was eerily quiet, we'd hear a loud splash. "WTF was that?" It could've been a seal jumping off a rock or it could've been a big great white chasing something, something also big, it might even have been a whale breeching. But we're here, under the famous Golden Gate Bridge and the first thing we'd guess is..."Jumper?"  It happens all the time... http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=ggb%20suicides&source=web&cd=2&ved=0CDgQFjAB&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tollroadsnews.com%2Fnode%2F1678&ei=snzAUaimDYrwiwLG3oC4DQ&usg=AFQjCNGbtgbAscvfgTZBf1LVCEAMev0cOQ&sig2=DeOmPW3TbttUYLH3p4VkBA&bvm=bv.47883778,d.cGE "Once every 18 days".

Ft. Point is a historical site of a time of war and fear. Now, the only fear left tangible is that of being hurled onto the rocks, eaten by a big shark or finding your tires deflated by local "surf Nazis" who heard you say "Frisco". This is the war we currently fight.
author: Robin Z.

description: An excellent spot to view the Golden Gate bridge! Found it by accident, as we were pretty much was doing the whole "create your own adventure" thing (e.g. shall we turn left or right? go over or under the bridge? etc.) and happily stumbled upon Fort Point. It's definitely a different and unique viewing point then the normal "next to the bridge", "on the bridge", "bridge far away in the distance/background". Sorry, I can't give directions, but I encourage you to find it and check it out!
author: Amanda Z.

description: Admission is FREE?! Awesome! Of course, they have a donation box if you wish to help with the upkeep of Fort Point. We drove down to the parking lot weaving past what seemed like a million runners. On the outside, it looks a lot smaller than it is once you walk in. You can sense all the history as you walk through different segments of the building. I'm not sure if they kept the sleeping quarters or if they remade it to seem that way. Either way, you get a glimpse of what it was like to be stationed here. Walking the upper most level is my favorite because of all the turrets lined up wall to wall.
