This is an amazing piece of history that I'm glad they've opened to the public. Aside from the history aspect, it's also an awesome place to take pictures of the fort itself and the bridge.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Back when I was in the 5th grade , we spent the better part of a month learning about the War Between the States( AKA The Second American Revolution AKA The War of Northern Aggression AKA The War Between the Americans and Yankees) - in other words, the conflict which we now erroneously call the Civil War . 

One of the most the most regrettable things about this period was that most of what we learned was pure Yankee/Union propaganda which omitted many of the facts behind the cause of conflict as well as the implications it eventually held for the nation.

OTOH, the most memorable aspect of that part of our history lesson was an overnight trip the entire class took to Fort Point. 

Even decades later I still recall the Park Rangers who were completely decked out in Union Army uniforms giving us a day long tour of the park and detailing all the historical facts behind the building of the Fort.

We were treated to everything from  a "show and tell" of every relevant  fact and chronological event in the Fort's past from it's conception as a defense against seaborne attacks/raids from Confederate maritime assets to the trivia regarding the highly detailed tactical architecture in the fort's avenues of access which heavily  favored it's defenders and would've presented a formidable multi layered obstacle to  any raiders.

Even down to the staircases which provided the defenders with an decided tactical advantage in everything from providing them superior fields of fire while denying same to any attacking force. It was even designed to favor the entrenched defenders when the fighting became hand to hand and bayonets and swords were being employed. 

This was back when the manual of arms all revolved around training and drilling the soldiers to use to use their right hands. Even if an individual was a Southpaw, he was expected to handle his arms with his right hand.

To give us a better feel for the day to day living conditions of the Union troops who were garrisoned here, after a day of seeing the sights and hearing the narrative of it's history, we had dinner in the very same mess hall that the fort's soldiers used over a century ago. 

We also spent the better part of the evening singing the various Civil War songs that we had learned in previous weeks. To this day, my favorite Civil War song is still the Southron version of _Battle Cry of Freedom_.


Another thing the teachers required of us during this trip was that we had to take turns getting up in the middle of the night and performing several hours of  sentry duties with our team mates which entailed walking rounds along the circumference of the fort's uppermost tiers.

We were armed with replica period rifles and given passwords to challenge any nearby patrols to be sure they were friendlies.

This night time patrol was made a bit more unsettling by some ghost stories/legends (particular to the Fort's past)the rangers had told us during a hike earlier in the night.

My only souvenir from this trip was a miniature brass cannon which I bought from the park's shop which now sits in a display case at my dad's house.
author: Temujin B.

description: Out of town visitors LOVE this view of "The Bridge". Better than just drivi g on it AND unique pics to take home.
author: Francis H.

description:
Why yes, you can tour this 19th-century gun fort at the mouth of the Bay.  

We encountered the Fort at about 5 pm, and although we didn't have much time, we entered for a quick trip around the inside.  Admission was free.  FREE.  

It was fun to dash up to the top of the walls and look out over the ocean.  Interpretive signs showed us how the old network of forts could defend the Bay with deadly gunfire, although it was never needed.  

The outside walls were all gun mounts, and the inside wall was the barracks and magazine.  We were able to walk around inside the interior ordinance storage rooms and the living areas.  The stone circular stairways reminded me of European castles.  The old lighthouse on top reminded me of the multiple uses the Fort has had over the years.  

Reconstruction was in progress, showing us how the military personnel lived while they were on tour here.  Their tours were typically much longer than ours was this weekend!  My Lady was very impressed with how big the enlisted bunks were, until we discovered they slept two to a bed.  Docents in costume made sure we left the Fort on time.  

Above the Fort was a trail that took us through coastal gun batteries and bunkers to the Golden Gate Bridge parking lot, where we could catch the 28 or 29 Muni busses.
author: David D.

description:
See, it works like this:

If you put the word "Fort" in front of anything, it's bound to make the Y chromosome get excited. You could mention "Fort Liverwurst" or "Fort Toxic Waste" or "Fort Pisspants" in a casual conversation, and any male within earshot is gonna perk up: "A fort, you say? Hell yeah, let's go!!!!"

All men revert to young boys when there's a fort to be explored.

Fortunately, Fort Point is actually fucking COOL. Sure, there are some historical placards; sepia-toned photos featuring people you've never heard of; and the occasional dude (or dudette) in retro-geek clothing who's forced to explain (for the millionth time) about ye olde anguish of trying to take a dump into a bedpan. But there are also brick warrens and tunnels and abandoned cannon posts to clamber on, over, through, and around. PLUS you get an amazing close-up view of the Golden Gate Bridge from directly underneath its criss-crossing red architectural beams.

Oh yeah, and it's FREE.

Ladies: Take your man here and watch him get excited in ways that don't involve Kleenex afterwards.

Men are just boys who shave. Fort Point proves it.
author: John G.

description:
People stationed here back in the day must have experienced quite a few trials and tribulations.

First of all, all of the bedrooms are connected by one long corridor. To get from one end of the hall to the other, you have to walk through every single room. Which means no privacy, no nookie with the hot nurses, and lots of draftiness.

Next, have you seen the size of some of those canon balls?! They're huuuge. While this ups the muscle and perhaps male attractiveness , they can't take advantage of their hotness due to lack of privacy (see above).

Then there's the wind. I mean, standing a good three feet from the edge, at the top look out stations, I STILL felt like I was going to go over the edge.

All of that being said, while it may have been uncomfortable and crappy for them back in the day, for us in the here and now with toasty cars to return to, Fort Point is a lot of fun. It gives you the chance to be your own explorer, parading up and down spiral staircases (don't break your neck), and peering into nooks and crannies. 

And for those of you who are a little *ahem* adventurous *ahem*, there are quite a few private, dark spaces, especially on the second floor. Maybe they managed to get some nookie back in the day after all!
author: Sierra S.

description:
I grew up shopping with my Lola at the base Commissary and PX. I played on the tank and straddled the cannons (do NOT get sewer-brain ideas, you pervs). every weekend, I insisted my Pappy take me to Fort Point so I could explore and pretend. I had a strange fascination for a saw that amputated a Yankee soldier's leg, gross but true. I stared endlessly at mid-19th century weaponry. there was a narrow spiral staircase made of iron which I climbed up & down repeatedly, causing people to wonder if I had a brain disorder or something. another fav of mine was the jail, sooooo cool ! to this day I am mystified how a child who was so enamored with this historical Civil War-era fort could never score higher than C's in history and social studies. quite peculiar.

this is the ONLY non-retail place in the whole world for a Prima who turns her nose at nature in favor of shopping malls and day spas. I stand by the rusty monster chains and dare the crashing waves to soak me. I imagine falling onto the rocks below. I gaze at the underneath of the GG Bridge and try to count the beams. this is where I behold two awe-inspiring man-made structures and marvel at how well they meld with the SF Bay. this is where, some days, I wish I were that 10-yr-old kid again, eating a tuna sandwich with her Pops while sitting on concrete dating from 1860. small pleasures are the greatest sometimes
author: Prima D.

description:
Free.  Need I say more?

150 year old fort form the Civil War era.  Once you enjoy the drive through the Marina and the Presidio you find yourself driving up to a huge brick fort.  To your left is a hillside and ultimately the Golden Gate Bridge.  To your right is the Bay.  Upon getting out of your car you are encompassed with all of the beauty of San Francisco and the rest of the Bay Area.

Come here with your spouse, your fling, your children, etc.  It is fun and a nice get away for all.  Our toddler was mesmerized by the cannons and the fact that he couldn't move the balls.  Even Michelle, who is usually bored at historical stuff, was in awe and felt eery seeing the living quarters.

I remember coming here all the time as a kid and I know I'll be bringing Dylan back as he grows up.  It is a cool place easily sparks up the imagination.
author: David W.

description:
When I was about 10, we took a school field trip out to Fort Point.  Back then I was bored and annoyed and didn't understand why we were walking around looking at old buildings when I could have been playing tether ball.  Now, as an adult, I have a newfound appreciation for the architecture, the history, and the fact that you can stare up at the Golden Gate Bridge from this locale.  

It's free, it's gorgeous, and it's San Francisco.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Gorgeous, gorgeous building and surroundings.  Huge, beautiful OLD (by US, west coast standards) building.  I was pleasantly surprised by the access allowed.  That is, you can touch and climb so many things (but as some posters pointed out, don't climb the roof wall!).  Incredible views on the roof, some of the best in the city.

Be prepared, it is quite cool in there.  Shady, and the wind whips right through.

Good hotdog cart on the way  :)
author: Moose C.

description:
This place is always fun to come to and always disappointing.

It's fun because driving down here is really interesting, and especially when you bring someone who's never been to San Francisco, the wonder of seeing the bottom of the bridge is awe-inspiring and sometimes kind of scary.  My favorite part of Fort Point is actually the view you get of the bridge from it.

The disappointing part of the fort is the insides.  The first time I came here, I felt disappointed in a Disneyland kind of way.  Actually, the fort on Tom Sawyer's Island at Disneyland is better than this fort.  I know it's authentically spartan, but they could have at least added more refurbished rooms so that people could get a sense of what this place was like when it was an actual fort.
author: John S.

description: This is what makes me feel so proud that I am a native San Franciscan.......
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Another spot with great views.  Living here, you can get spoiled with all the great views.  

The road leading to the fort is where (I think) Kim Novak was teetering over the surf in the early part of Vertigo.  

The fort is an antebellum structure similar to the more famous Fort Sumter in Charleston.  You definitely must go to the upper tier on the ocean side and check out the great views (and the gale force winds)!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I only moved to the area recently, and I am still in tourist mode. With that said, Fort Point is a place I will return to, long after tourist mode has worn off.  On my way there, I suffered the painful drive down 19th Avenue (7 1/2 miles took over an hour...) to 101N before turning off at the last exit right before the Golden Gate Bridge.  I found parking without a problem and relaxed in the parking lot for a few minutes looking up at the Golden Gate Bridge and out into the water at all the birds and seals. After entering Fort Point, I spent about 45 minutes just wandering around the different floors, walking through rooms, taking pictures, and oohing and ahhing over the views.  There were several plaques, pictures, and different areas set up to show what the food rations, bedding, surgeon's office, etc. looked like.  So the trip had a free history lesson built in.  There is also a Visitor's Center which I went in to warm up, and left with hot coffee and a few postcards (yes, I am still a tourist)...

Fort Point is a great place to look up at the Golden Gate Bridge, see the city from a new vantage point, and watch fishermen, birds, seals, and surfers.  Definitely worth the trip whether you are a longtime resident or tourist.  And it's free!
author: Heather F.

description:
As a born, raised, and now after six years elsewhere in the US, living in SF I love this city.

Today was an absolutely beautiful day. Me and the bf biked from South Beach to Fisherman's Warf over to Fort Point, and back into the center of the City (our apt in Nob Hill).

Some of the road in Crissy Field park going into Fort Point need to be re-paved fro bikes, roller bladers, walkers, etc to enjoy.m But the rough road was worth it.

We arrived at the very north west tip of the City and turned around to enjoy the view. Our response:

"Hey where is the Fog? I doesn't look like the City."

What a gorgeous way to spend an early Sunday afternoon in the City.
author: Sara K.

description:
Young at heart or a kid yourself, it's a great place to visit.  

Kids will like all the spooky spiral stairways and cannons.  It's a fun way for them to interact with history.  The fact it's a real live fort will capture any person's imagination.  

Plus the site has great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz and the city.   So it's fun and romantic.  

With free parking in front you can drive there.  

Those who are more adventurous can make a day of it.  Ride your bike following the bay, through Crissy Fields to the point right underneath the Golden Gate Bridge.

Opened on the weekends only, it looks beautiful in the fog and a perfect activity for a sunny day. 

Immature confession:  A great place for hide and seek, just respect the visitors around you.
 
I highly recommend this site.
author: Marlenee H.

description:
I usually frequent the pier that is located a hop, skip, and a stones throw away from Ft. Point (which is great!).  I normally come here to go either fishing, and/or crabbing, though more recently for the latter.  The view on the right day is really nice -the Golden Gate Bridge on one side, and a very nice view of San Francisco on the right.  What more could you want?  Well, if you go to the pier, be sure to bring a jacket because it does get very cold (because of the high wind chill factor on most days). 
Parking lot is open to the public, though on nice days be sure to come early, because it will go quick!
Can't think of any reason to dock off any stars.
author: Anthony L.

description:
A great San Francisco experience. I love coming here to watch the pelicans, awesome in their straight, single file formations, cruising into  and out of the Golden Gate beneath the bridge. The view from the ramparts is amazing, you're at the absolute crux of the peninsula here.
Another interesting thing is it's an entirely different weather system on the north & west side of the fort as it is on the south/southeast, due to the way the windstream and shadows work. Also the interior, well preserved, is a good history lesson. An excellent place to take your tourist relatives.
author: Mark L.

description:
Want the best view of the GG?  Come here.

Dont forget to bring $5 for the Organic Hot Dog stand at Chrissy Field.
author: Cara M.

description: Fort Point is a great historical site in San Francisco just under the south tower of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Fort Point was completed in 1861 and was built as a deterrent against naval attack on California.  Parking is limited at the site, so early arrival on a non-holiday weekend is best.  For more information on the site and directions, visit the website at http://www.nps.gov/fopo/planyourvisit/directions.htm.
author: Chris F.

description: This historic fort has impressive views of the bay from UNDER the golden gate bridge.  Take the time and go visit.  You can walk there from fisherman's wharf or drive there.  Either way, the family will have a nice time.  Free to enter; donations taken by the National Park service.
author: Mark F.

description: Wow, compared to all of the other 5-star reviews I feel kind of like an ass. I'm a history nerd and all but nothing really struck me about this particular historical site in San Francisco. Fort Point is a neat place to visit if you are in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. It could just be that I am way more fascinated with the ginormous bridge that stands above it with its chest puffed so boldly. I've come across several interesting photo shoots going on at this place, namely a retro sailor-themed wedding and a motorcycle cop shoot. Great view of downtown from here as well. However, I recommend just checking it out from the bridge :)
author: Leigh W.

description:
I think i have spent more time at Da Office"Fort Point" than most people have. I've sailed , water skied and paddled around the tower many times since the "70's. I've surfed it for more than 30 years and have many great stories i can tell. The suicide jumpers, the Heavy Local Scene of Surfers,and not to mention the local sea life that rules there. The Rangers, the Bridge Patrol and Park Police are an awesome bunch of people who are an asset to San Francisco. I love the Majestic Views and the adverse weather and conditions there. It all makes you feel ALIVE.
FPG Forever
author: Larry Y.

description:
I have some of the best, fondest memories of this place and they were all with my father. He would walk while I rode my bike steadily along the water from the Presidio all the way up to the Golden Gate bridge. With the breeze mussing your hair and hitting your face (sometimes, with a vengeance), it was and always will be a place that provides inspiration and a place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city streets. 

The Golden Gate bridge, the military museum inside the Fort and the many fisherman along the pier willing to show you their catches for the day are just a few things to admire while you're there. One of the reasons for anyone to visit Fort Point would have to be Hitchcock's homage to the iconic bridge in his film Vertigo. 

Just don't try to re-enact the scene...
author: Dorothy S.

description: WoW. Very historical place to check out. Bring a jacket because it gets very windy once you step foot inside the fort. Cannons were located at every level of the fort and were of different sizes too. The gun powder room was filled with barrels and barrels of black powder as if it was a winery. When you get to the top level, the winds were super strong. Excellent view of Golden Gate Bridge. You can watch the  giant container ships pass under the bridge. Just remember to bring a camera and a jacket.
author: Gordon C.

description:
*referring to the pier*

I would give it five stars, but it gets insanely windy there! I can't change mother nature but I sure wish I can. Anyway, this is one of the most beautiful places in the city. During a clear day, you get a beautiful view of the bridge and the city and during a clear night you get to see the city light up. 
Fishing isn't bad here either. During the summer, Halibut and Stripers run through. There are a bunch of perch as well as the occasional rockfish,  sharks, and rays. If only the wind would go away! If you're in the city, you should definitely drop by.

Theres a big parking lot right next to the pier so there is no worries about parking.
author: Michael T.

description: Great history - strange being on the top and looking up at the under belly of the GGB - but cool
author: Peter S.

description:
WOW awesom-mazing-tacular place for photos. Old landmark building, water, and the *BEST* view of the Golden Gate up close? All in one.

And it's free too!! Amazing place to check for photos, it's easy to spend 2 hours just wandering around and taking snaps. Loved going up to the roof level and taking pics *right* under the bridge. You can get a great view of the whole bay and of several of the SF Piers.

Parkings not too bad, but it can get a bit congested later in the day so try to get there before 1 or 2.
author: Stephen W.

description:
When we were at the top by the GG Bridge, it was really windy and a bit chilly, but once we walked down to the actual Fort Point where the beach was, the weather was soo lovely. There were so many opportunities down there to take a good and clear shot with the GG Bridge in the background of your photo. 

There's like a cafe/gift shop down by Fort Point too! They have lots merchandise promoting GREEN. love it. 

The beach is small but not too small. It's so lively full of kids and young adults tanning. I love it. I would definitely come here to lay on the sand instead of Ocean or Baker's Beach. It's much cleaner! If you don't want to lay on the sand, there's plenty of pleasant grassy fields to lay on too. There were a bunch of couples just sitting on the grass reading the newspaper. Very cute. 

It was also a very nice walk along the Marina from North Point. The houses we admired were huge and they will get you jealous fosho.
author: Bets Y.

description:
The Fort Dates back to the 1850's and is a National Treasure and a hidden gym for the Bay area. Many people drive over the Golden Gate bridge daily and never know it is located right under them which is a shame.

This 150 year brick fort never saw any military battles but it is well preserved and gives you a sense of history. The views from the Fort are also very beautiful and you can really understand the size and scope of the bridge from here too.

On a nice day you may see some surfers or fisherman in this area. It is more than worth taking an hour or so to walk around and explore. I have been several times myself.
author: Kevin F.

description: No admission fee, part of the GGNRA. You gotta come here, not just for the views but for the historic part.  Lots of posted history information, cannons and other old relics on display.   Best views of the GG Bridge, especially if a large freighter or tanker ship sails underneath.  You cannot get any closer except being in a boat yourself.   It's real windy here, so be sure to bring a warm coat.  It's a real old Army fort, so the stairs have no handrails and are steep.  There are dangerous areas, like up on the upper roof, so watch your step and hold on to the real young kids.  There's a very small parking lot in front for maybe 25 cars, so finding an open parking spot can be a challenge on the weekends.
author: Larry G.

description:
A beautiful point for pointless diversion.

Also free, so dare I say, completely affortable.
author: GIR ..

description:
About a few weeks back, my boyfriend & I decided to take a hike to Crissy Field & then forged onto Fort Point.

We took a look at a Black History display of old photos they had there & it was mainly about a few of the Buffalo Soldiers that were from San Francisco & who went out to serve in the Philippines during the "Spanish American" war...we both stumbled upon it & I think we were both taken aback b/c it's the kind of history that you don't ever, ever get taught in the core curriculum in school growing up...we were both so glad we got to see the displays & the photographs b/c we learned a part of BOTH of our ancestors histories & how they intertwined...
 
Anyway, a granddaugther of one of those Buffalo Soldiers, wrote a memoir of her life & her grandpa's...she had a reading yesterday that I missed out there in Oakland but here's more info. in the article about her book, if you're interested, "Twenty-Five Chickens and a Pig for a Bride: Growing Up in a Filipino Immigrant Family" (T'Boli Publishing, 2006).

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/03/08/DDG0GOGEOH1.DTL&hw=buffalo+soldier&sn=001&sc=1000
author: Elle F.

description:
Not as cool as Fort Baker, IMHO...

But a wonderful place to walk around, the history is fantastic, they have some fun events, great view of the city and damn near everything, and I could watch those surfers for hours.  And hell Vertigo was filmed there. 

A real must for people that want a nice long walk around the city.  Or just to drive up and see the views.  One of the nicest spots around.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: This is a great site with great exhibits.  We really enjoyed it.  Bring warm clothing.
author: Steve R.

description:
I freaking love Fort Point! It's my new favorite old timey place in San Francisco (sorry Sutro Baths....maybe if you weren't so ruin-y). The Fort is massive and beautiful and WILDLY UNSUPERVISED! Seriously, there were only two guys watching the whole place and you know they're only there because they are retired and want an excuse to wear civil war uniforms every day (also known as: my future). I was like a kid in a giant, decrepit candy store! 

The most amazing part was definitely going up to the roof of the fort. The wind was so strong I couldn't breathe!

My new goal is to set up camp in one of the dark corners of the fort and hope no one notices that I'm living there.
author: Larisa S.

description: Great view of the golden gate bridge. You are pretty much underneath the bridge. Has plenty of free parking and seems like a good place to run to.
author: Jannet V.

description:
Absolutely beautiful! 

Check out the Fort and gaze up at the Golden Gate Bridge!  Bring a camera and watch the few brave surfers coming in with the tides.
author: Anna R.

description:
Came here recently with a friend of mine who is relocating back to South Carolina. Wanted her to see some of the sights of SF that she hadn't seen yet. It's beautiful here and the history of the Fort is super cool. 

Depending on what time of day you are likely to see many a hot surfer catching some waves right by the rocks. Makes your skin crawl thinking they might hit their head and die. 

This is a must see if visiting or have someone visiting. Just don't get a flat tire. AAA Roadside call center has no f-ing idea where Fort Point is and demands that you give them two cross streets and a numbered address of where you are. Hmmmm....so is the San Francisco Bay a cross street? Thank god some surfers changed the tire for us. Apparently it takes 5 of them to change one tire. But we didn't' complain.
author: Heather L.

description:
There's not a lot here except the scenery, which if you're into it's GREAT.  It's windy, so be sure to bring a coat (my mistake).  Great for photographers looking for some new subjects, a lot of interesting tourists, and great views of the Golden Gate and the bay.  

The only thing stopping this from having 5 stars, in my humble opinion, is that there isn't much to DO here but look around, take some photos if that's your thing, and read a few plaques.  No interactive history for the kiddies or anything.
author: Trisha F.

description: I've been on the tour several time's since I was a kid & still find it very interesting. I've also been here a number of time's fishing. Like many have said, don't forget a jacket, even on sunny day's!
author: Ed S.

description:
I used to go here for field trips when I was a little kid..  and it's always that thing that you see... not quite as prominent as Alcatraz, but still one of those historic fixtures.

Also gets points because it was in the Hitchcock thriller Vertigo too...
author: Eric K.

description: This is a beautiful place to come to on a clear day. The upward view of the Golden Gate is only part of what makes it memorable. There is a long walking path, you're right by the water's edge, and you can stop at the cafe for a really tasty (and pretty) latte. I've only been here on weekends, but imagine it's a lot quieter during the week, and would make for a good jogging/strolling area.
author: Sonia M.

description: Fantastic place to visit while touring around San Fran and the Golden Gate area!
author: Roman K.

description:
This is my turn-around spot on my run.
Truly one of the best runs in the world.  I feel so lucky to have this as part of my routine.
Don't forget to slap the hands on the fence before you turn back and make your way back towards the city.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I've never been inside Fort Point before!  I always run down, hit Hopper's Hands, and then start my run back to North Beach.

This weekend we had family in town though and we drove over and got out to look around.  The Fort is sooooooooooo cool.  (And I never use repetitive vowels to make a point, so pay attention!)

Climb up to the fourth floor tower just under the bridge and you get the coolest vantage point in the city.  To your left is the ocean, to your right is the bay and the city sky line and above you is the Golden Gate Bridge.  It is just so freaking awesome that even some one as scared of heights as me couldn't get enough of it.
author: Jessica B.

description: Amazing location, if you like hiking and the bridge, park your car nearby and just have a walk!
author: Chris B.

description:
This is a MUST SEE for visitors and locals alike  to experience: 

Be sure to notice the old tombstones embedded in the breakwaters on the drive up to Fort Point.. They are there due to the 1906 earthquake and subsequent  bay-fill.  

 The historical tour of the fort is something you could expect back east - yet no place has the unique views of the Pacific expanse - as well as the the overhead view of the incomparable Golden Gate Bridge.

Priceless!  And then sit every one down for a screening of Vertigo, complete with the immortal Hitchcock actors!
author: hugh c.

description: Really neat place. Interesting historical value plus excellent view of Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Lori B.

description: SUPER COLD. But awesome view, dogs aren't allowed on that pier though :(
author: Hana G.

description:
For short runs I use it as my halfway point...."Now all I have to do is run back!"
For long runs its the marker of the last leg of my journey...."Now all I have to do is make it home."

Hopper's Hands!!!
author: Rachael W.

description:
Hands down this is the best vantage point for seeing the Golden Gate Bridge. Locals, take your out-of-town visitors here or you're doing them a disservice. The tour was pretty cool when I was nine years old, but I think it's the view that makes the place so priceless.

To really give your visitors a taste of SF history, push one of them into the Bay to show them how Kim Novak did it in Vertigo. Just kidding. The rangers won't let you do it anyway.
author: Aaron L.

description: Certainly an interesting spot. It is a bit of history to take in while in San Francisco. The fort is under the Golden Gate Bridge, and it can be a bit uncomforable if the weather doesn't cooperate (making the gift shop the driest and warmest place to be in the fort...go figure). The staff was good, but they weren't all together on when the place opened, and one fellow even took me to the wrong "visitor center" (which was still interesting but not what I was originally looking for, but it all worked out).  Check this place out if you're in the area.
author: Patrick D.

description: Fort Point is a great place to explore especially for Civil War and history buffs. Many people miss this wonderful piece of American history when they visit San Francisco. Unfortunately due to federal government budget cuts upkeep of the displays and Fort Point itself have been neglected. You would think even Republicans would want to keep our historical landmarks maintained. Always take a jacket with you when you visit, even if it's a sunny warm day. The breeze at the fort is amazingly chilly and forceful.
author: Richelle N.

description:
Most beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge ever.  Captured expertly in "Vertigo," it is highly suggestible that you do NOT, repeat, DO NOT jump into the bay like Kim Novak!

But, you too can take Hitchcock-esque photos of the bridge from this very spot.

The Fort itself is pretty amazing too, but shut down due to retrofit.
author: David S.

description:
Awesome way to get right under the bridge.... kinda.... after Sept 11th they've closed down the underside often blockaded by law enforcement. Way to keep people from jumping. 

A great place to run & watch the fog roll in. "hold me i'm cold!"
author: Eugene G.

description: A hidden gem!  NO ONE GOES HERE, not the snooty locals (I am one) or the annoying tourists.  Only open on weekends, it is a nearly pristene 1850's fortification.  It is FREE to go inside and climb all throughout it.  Cannons from the spanish era up to the civil war are inside.  You can also go on the top level and get a great view out of the bay, marina, and bridge.  STOP BY it is FREE and worth it.
author: Owen S.

description: If the weather is clear in SF, then you have to make a point of going to Fort Point.  The location (directly under the Golden Gate) and the history make it a perfect stop on a tour of the city.  We took a group of kids (ages 7-10) and they loved it!  Plus, it is FREE (but we did make a donation).
author: M M.

description: A place to take a picture of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Ronald N.

description:
Nothing better than the view from the top of fort point - western view is out to sea and amazing with views of both Point Bonita Lighthouse to the northwest and Lincoln Park to the southwest.

Eastern view is the city, alcatraz and the east bay (on a clear day).  

North is the bridge. And you cannot get a better shot of the towers from anywhere else - its amazing.

And just below the bridge are all the surfers and seals - its a great spot to just enjoy the scenery.

Inside the fort there are some great historical spots and amazing circular stone staircases - its simply an amazing place to go - whether you are local or visiting - it never gets old.
author: Deanna H.

description: Wow, this place is full of Civil War history. I especially enjoyed the lesson on how to load and fire a cannon. They have a mini library, too where they sell books on Alcatraz and San Francisco.
author: Thea T.

description: Loved it. Reminded me of 6th grade! Hadn't been there since. Great for you to go out and enjoy the day sight seeing and it's FREE!! Gatta love it!
author: Paty V.

description: The sun was shining and the point was calling me 'Patrick get you fat ass of the couch and dust of your bicycle and come see me" Well I ventured down there and it was glorious!  The point was busy, surfers, biker, jogger and me!  It's great part of the City if you have never been GO!
author: Patrick F.

description:
in 5th grade we got to come here and spend the night! that was the coolest thing ever when i was a kid! our class was divided into different civil war army groups and this was part of our civil war learning. we got to go on tours and eat like they would have and all that stuff. 

the best part was that they had us all take hour long shifts overnight to keep watch. i remember that being really fun and scary. that was 17 years ago or so and i haven't been back since. but i really want to! and i still need to walk across that bridge thing next to it.
author: Eli G.

description: I biked all the way here before with a bunch of little kids. I thought that the trip would be more uneasy but it was quite a easy bike trip considering that I am a bad biker. The waves crashing on the rocks just seems to calm me down. The Fort itself is pretty cool because it is from the war.
author: Janet Z.

description: The place is a great part of California history and San Francisco history. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Fort Point itself, and the Pacific Ocean. If you are lucky, you can see large cruises and special ships go under the Golden Gate Bridge. Parking can be a pain, but it is worth going to. Many surfers come out to surf here as well.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: Great place for a stroll and enjoy the view of Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Daisy S.

description:
i love to cast out a line, prop my fishing pole up against the dock, and smoke a cigarette at sunset.  

fort point is what this great city is about - freedom to be who you wanna be, freedom to do what you wanna do, freedom to go wherever you wanna go.

when i win the superbowl and someone asks me where i'm going...i'm gonna say "i'm going to fort point!"
author: Ray R.

description: Fort point is one of the coolest things about San Francisco. I love to walk out here and be near the bay. Great as a place to walk to and just tour around. Recommended for out of towners.
author: Sven S.

description: Weekend morning walk with a coffee?  Blowing off steam on a run after work?  Sunset and a cocktail?  Take the dog for a swim?  No better place to go than Crissy Field and Fort Point.  Having such an amazing place right here in the city is one of THE defining aspects of what makes San Francisco great.
author: Brad K.

description:
landmark review 100 for a san francisco landmark!

i'm always a tourist in sf, wanting to find the next most jaw-dropping spot in the bay to gush about. 

well -- i think i found it.

it's sooooo typically san franciscan - windy weather with waves crashing up against the rocks (bring a hat, hair tie, or something with a hoody!). surfers and wind surfers. a stunning up close and personal view of the golden gate bridge.  tourists. a straight shot view of all of san francisco - i realized this weekend that it glows on clear days. it really does.

a small trek up a few flights of stairs and you reach the top of the Fort itself -- a climb well worth it, as you are rewarded with a 360 degree view of ocean, marin, east bay, alcatraz, sf, more sf, and more sf. it looks like they're building it up into more of a historical museum at the moment, so i look forward to going back!

a wonderful and magical spot for photographs, to just sit on the edge of the city and stare, and to high-five those incredibly fit runners and cyclists. give yourself a high-five when you get there too for making it to this five star fun, free, and fabulous Fort! (woohoo!)

allow me to echo everyone else's sentiment: if you haven't gone - GO! you'll never want to leave (except when you can't feel your ears no 'mo).
author: Diana L.

description: This is one of my favorite places to bring friends from out of town.  The view is startling in its beauty.  From here, you have the best vantage point to see the entire City, from the GG Bridge, to the Palace of Fine Arts, to Coit Tower and that silly pointy skyscraper whose name is currently escaping me...
author: Sid D.

description: Being a native San Franciscan I am ashamed to say that I never got to visit this place up until couple of years ago, and I don't know why it took me so long to visit. Fort Point is awesome, and I recommend that you have to come visit this place especially if you have kids. I will no longer take for granted places like this ever again.
author: Rommel N.

description:
How did it happen that I've lived in the area so many years, and never even HEARD of Fort Point? Thank god for curious aunts, that's all I can say. 
After a long, lingering lunch at Greens, the two of us walked along the Marina, and my aunt said, "What is that building under the bridge?' To which I responded, "There is no building under the bridge. You must be thinking of someplace else." 
We quibbled over the finer points of this argument for a good ten minutes, then decided to go check out the fictional building for ourselves. We had no idea how to get there, so just kept driving west, past Crissy Field. 
Ten minutes later and no building in sight, I was soooo ready to say "Ha, told you so!". That's when we saw the sign for Fort Point. And when we finally got out of the car, I was in awe. Does a better vista exist? I don't know it. 
After I stopped gaping long enough to talk, we decided to explore the fort. A quick jog up three flights put us right under the Golden Gate bridge. Right then, with the wind whipping through my hair, staring out at the bay and up at the soaring beams of the bridge, I knew why I live in San Francisco. This is a city with no equal.
author: Purnima M.

description: BEST way to start the day - a walk/jog/run from the "monkey bars" to Fort Point and back. approximately 6 miles. Walking toward the GG bridge and the bird sanctuary is a great reminder to be expansive... and to breathe.... love it. San Francisco's finest!
author: Victoria Z.

description: It's the arpit of the Golden Gate Bridge!  Yes, there's a lot of history to this place.  While the civil war was being fought mainly on the east coast, the Union thought it necessary to build a fort in San Francisco.  Very interesting.  The view is beautiful, and despite the corrosive salty seaspray, the fort is in very good condition.  I would recommend taking kids here for a little history lesson, or just to take a look around if you're giving out of towners a tour of the Golden Gate Bridge.  But is this a really must see 5 star destination?  I don't think so.
author: Tony L.

description:
Oh, hello there. Looking for an awesome review about Fort Point? Well, you've stumbled across the right one! But before we begin, I'd just like to point out that my review may be a teeny-tiny bit biased because I uh...well, I work at Fort Point. I'd also like to slap a disclaimer on here to let my fellow yelpers know that the views and opinions expressed in this review are solely that of Tevina's and do not reflect the National Parks Service nor the Golden Gate National Rec. Area nor the Department of the Interior  in anyway. Tevina is a park ranger by day, and crazy, cackling yelper by night - it is indeed night time right now, so prepare for some crazy. 

Great, now that -that's- out of the way, let us begin. Fort Point is the place to be whether you're looking for a low energy, but exciting activity for your 'out of towner' friends, or just a cool stroll on a hot day (it's seriously like ten degrees lower inside the fort than right outside. I'm not kidding). The view of the GG bridge is breathtaking, the rich history and architectural work is astounding. 

But what is there to do at this old brick fort? Well, there are tours twice a day, as well as cannon drill demonstrations. No, we don't actually shoot the cannons, but we engage the audience by letting them participate in the drills and feel free to throw your arms in the air and yell "BOOOOOOOM" in the hallways after the person pulls the primer from the cannon vent. Oh, and did I mention you get to do the drill with an AUTHENTIC 12-pounder Napoleon cannon from the civil war era? HOW COOL IS THAT!?

Anyway, if interactive and walking around isn't your kinda thing, there are videos that are shown every day that are played inside our tiny theater which is the perfect escape from the cold and wind outside because in order to go into the theater, you have to go to the bookstore. The bookstore, oh god, I love that place. Imagine if you were climbing Mt. Everest and all of a sudden you see a cabin with a fire place brewing and hot cocoa being served in the middle of it all; see now the bookstore in the fort, it's like that. 

The best part of visiting Fort Point is the admission. It's absolutely FREE! All the programs (the tours, the demonstrations, the videos, the exhibits) are FREE! Come in for 5 minutes, stroll around for 2 hours or even spend the whole day there! It's absolutely free to get in. But one important thing I must mention is that the fort closes promptly at 5pm. The upper tiers close 10 minutes beforehand, so if you arrive at say, 4:52 we can't let you up there. Even if you came all the way from Kazakhstan and it's your last day in the bay area and you just want to go up to the roof for 1.5 minutes; you can't go up. Why? Because we're closing. And I want to go home so I can eat and drive all the way across the city to make it in time for my evening class. Feel me? Oh, and we don't take bribes either. So don't offer me $20 to sneak you up there. Come between 10am - 450pm and it'll all be gravy, baby.
author: Tevina T.

description:
I like Ft. Point.  It sort of remids me of a fishbowl.  The surf there can get good, but it is rather sketchy, clearly.  The vibe is not great.  Most surfer there are good people and are cool if you are respectful and patient...but others are downright salty if they don't know you.  
I was there one evening,  and the sun was going down. there was only 2 people in the water, and out of nowhere a mass of birds started feeding on the surface near by.  Being in the water became downright creepy.  Not much scares me more than seeing birds feeding on the surface when I am surfing... The surf was pleasant that day, and there was 2 people out, great right?  We all looked at each other...b/c of the bird action, and they rode the next waves in... I simply went in as fast as I could.  It's is a eerie place for me, but from a tourist perspective I think it is fascinating... Very cool.  I don't make the time to go there enough... The perspectives are quite impressive.
author: gordon w.

description: Seeing as it was so clear out and that it finally warmed up a little bit I was scooting about town today when I meandered over to Fort Point.  I've lived  in San Francisco for 5 years and while I've been to Fort Point, I've never actually been inside the Fort.  What an amazing piece of history, free and open to the public.  It's the only brick fort on the west coast and it's full of very cool stuff.  Do yourself a favor, check this place out.
author: Jeffrey F.

description: Very cool spot in San Fran.  On certain days when the surf is right, there are a handful of amazing surfers tearing it up under the bridge.  Swimming right there with them was a sea lion just checkin them out!  If you're feeling ballsy, slip around the fence for an even better view.   You'll feel pretty small & insignificant next to that huge bridge and crashing surf.
author: Tara G.

description: One of my favorite places to go and gander at the marvelous view of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Originally a fort during the Civil War, it is now a historical landmark with an excellent view from below the great bridge.  You can watch ships as they enter the bay, watch the sail boats and various wind surfers as they cross the choppy waters or just hold on to a loved one and enjoy the atmosphere.  This is also the famed location from Hitchcock's masterpiece "Vertigo" when Kim Novak jumps into the bay and James Stewart saves her from drowning.  Definitely worth a visit if you're a fan of the film, as I am.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Fort Point is a magical place.  My imagination goes wild at the Fort and I pretend it is wartime; firing imaginary cannons at imaginary ships.  The tourists love it!
author: Patrick A.

description: Way underrated by locals and tourists alike! Fort Point itself is a cool place to go back in history, but the surrounding location is what brought me here. I love the perspective of the GG Bridge from underneath, plus you have a view of both the city and the bay. The BEST part about a trip to Fort Point though, is seeing the surfers catch the break created by the bridge. There is a handful of old surfer dudes that apparently come out daily to get their wave fix. (I've only seen them on weekend mornings.) Bring a camera, grab the kids, and brave the likely fog- it is worth it!
author: Kate G.

description: Fort Point happens to be my turn around point when I run at Chrissy Field. I often pause here to take a break and take in the beauty that is the Golden Gate Bridge and a San Francisco icon.
author: Alia D.

description: I run out to this place every Saturday morning.  I like the hands of encouragement tacked on the building.  They are two hand prints that signify that I am half way done with my run and it is time to get my butt running back towards home.
author: Julie R.

description: Whenever I have visitors from out of town, I make sure to take them to Fort Point. On a clear and sunny day, you can see the entire view of SF and Sausalito. It's so cool looking under the Golden Gate Bridge.  Fort Point is one of the hidden tresures of SF.
author: Trish P.

description: One of my favorite spots in San Francisco. Take your out-of-towners for some photo ops or take your date and cuddle while enjoying the views.  From here, you can see a panoramic view of the San Francisco skyline, Alcatraz, Sausalito, and look under the bridge (all on a clear day). Best to come here when it's nice and sunny; otherwise, all you'll see is a white sheet of fog.
author: Zell C.

description: Great place to watch surfers ride waves right underneath Golden Gate Bridge.   When it's good (winter and fall on bigger swells, incoming tide after low tide), it's a amazing to see surfers catch waves that can wrap from all around the outer point through the inside.  Occasionally barrells, heavy local crew of surfers.   With the currents, cold, and local vibe, it's an experts only spot for surfers; but the best place to watch surf in San Francisco.
author: Evan A.

description:
i almost drowned here when i body boarded several years ago. despite that mishap, i still remember the day i took my board underneath that huge golden gate and almost past the bridge to view the vast pacific ocean. ill never forget that. i felt so small under that huge bridge and even larger vast openess of the pacific ocean.

even if you dont get out past fort point, the point itself is worth a stop over. its got beautiful picture spots and awesome angles of the bridge. this spot cant be beat.
author: Riff Raff V.

description: Booooom! Fort Point is awesome. Used to go here from school every couple of years. Tons of cool cannons. The place was literally built around them and now they can't be taken out because they are so big. It's an awesome SF landmark that doesn't get too many tourists. It's also a cool place that you can look up at the bridge from.
author: Erik S.

description: I went to school in San Diego and I moved away to Chicago. All the while it was this place that pulled on my heart strings, so I finally moved back. Where else in the world does man made structures fit in to the geographic landscape so well? If there is another place, I haven't found one. And Fort Point is a great place to admire the symbiotic relationship between man and nature!
author: Douglas L.

description: Need to satisfy your craving for Civil War Era weapons? Then Fort Point is the place for you. You can learn about the history of San Francisco, and after it's all said and done, you could walk along the Golden Gate Bridge, or take a whiff of the fresh Pacific Ocean Water.  Fort Point is the stuff film is made for, so share the picturesque views you're able to capture and send them to someone.  After your outing, if you're up for it, head to the Marin Headlands to breathe some more air filtered by nature.
author: brenda b.

description: Ahh...that kind of sums up the the feeling I get when I set my eyes on this beautiful place. With the most picturesque views of the Golden Gate Bridge, it's a perfect place to continue your stroll after hitting the Palace of Fine Arts and Crissy Field. You will find lots of people jogging, riding bikes or taking their dogs for a walk in the area. Climb the steps for a great view.
author: Marcie L.

description: I found this little hidden area one time just driving around the Presidio. It's by far the best view of the bridge, since you get to look up at it from the base. (The other view I like, is from the Marin side looking down from the west with view of the city behind the bridge.)
author: qirk z.

description: I was surprised to find out that you can actual enter the fort building itself and walk around in an open museum sort of way.  The stairwells leading to the top of the fort are currently blocked off, I am not certain why or when they will be reopened.  I understand the the views from atop the fort are spectacular.  Perhaps those views are what would make it a 5-star attraction.
author: daniel g.

description: Nice view, but really it's just a parking lot. Good place to ride the bike to and from though (no hills on the way).
author: Heidi P.

description:
killer views of the gg bridge
hardcore surfers 
the sea air is very refreshing
easy parking
be sure to bring a jacket and gloves
author: Amber A.

description: What a spectacular view of the Golden Gate Bridge from here!!!  Plus, it's a piece of SF history.  We were walking at Crissy Field and ended up at the fort...just as a guided tour was starting!  It was very interesting and had lots of information and anecdotes.  We only wished we stumbled upon it a bit earlier for the cannon shooting demonstration.  Bring a jacket because even on a warm day in the rest of the City, the chilly ocean wind can be daunting.
author: Lew D.

description: great views of the city!  it might get a little touristy for that very same reason, but there's a reason tourists flock there.  it's f'ing gorgeous!  if you're a history buff, there's lots of good info about san francisco's role in the civil war.  i'm from the south so most of that was news to me.
author: Aimee C.

description: This is a cool place to visit for sure. There aren't a lot of other places where you can easily see the Golden Gate Bridge from below. I think they still do their docent tours here. I remember doing that many years ago. You can watch people fish and oftentimes there are surfers there too (looks dangerous with all those rocks!). You used to be able to sneak around the Fort on the far side, but they fenced that off some years ago. You used to be able to get almost to the other side to a spot where you could see the open ocean. I guess they decided to limit access because it gets dangerous when the waves are strong and for security reasons too. I would very much recommend Fort Point as a quick stop if you're taking in the sights nearby. If you're a tourist, definitely check out the tourist area at the Golden Gate Bridge and also consider checking out Crissy Field back down the road a ways for a nice walk/view of the Bay.
author: Al B.

description: the fort is a little piece of SF history, and it provides amazing views of the bridge. remember a jacket, though. it gets really windy and cold on the top!
author: Bee H.

description: The most fantastic views in the city. We are so lucky to be able to run along the water to Fort Point, must be the most scenic run in the country by far. Also a great place to bring out of towners to walk through the fort or check out the surfers.
author: Cbr A.

description: As a native Californian, I am embarrassed to say that I never knew Fort Point was open to the public.  The vicinity, sure, but not the building itself right under the Golden Gate.  I'd always assumed it was off limits, entrance authorized only to maintenance workers and bridge personnel. I have to say, after visiting for the first time yesterday it is now one of my very favorite places in all of northern Cal!  Free parking, free entrance (donation requested, but still...), not crowded even on a sunny summer Sunday afternoon, and the most awe inspiring views of the bridge, the bay, the city.  I'm still swooning the next day. Our family was looking for a super cheap, but fun, way to celebrate a belated Father's Day, and did we ever find it for the cost of a tank of gas.  Picnic lunch from home, leash up the dog, drive to the city from Auburn, lunch at Crissy Field, treat the puppy to little waves at the shoreline, walk along the bay to Fort Point, back to the Warming Hut for a java, drive over the GG on the way home.  A perfect day!
author: Kristine O.
